video_title: Leavitt SLAMS Dems: 'Completely lost their minds’

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Here now with the Hannity Washington briefing, White House Press Secretary Caroline Leavitt is with us. Let's start, you know, we're a week away from what is officially six months of the administration. What I mentioned was pretty much a tip of the iceberg in terms of  the administration's success. I don't think enough people get that 30,000-foot view and look at the big picture, because I really can't think of a presidency in the modern era that has accomplished that much so quickly. Is the administration going to celebrate it in some way?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, with President Trump, we work hard every day, and we are going to continue to work hard to deliver on all of the campaign promises that he made to the American public. But it surely has been an extraordinary six-month start to the four years that President Trump has been blessed with  back in the Oval Office. And let's go back to one year ago yesterday, where God saved the life of President Trump so he could save this country and return to this city where so much change is needed. And look at what he has done with the border. You just laid it out, Sean, the most secure border in our nation's history. A president who has the backs of our law enforcement officers every day  Those law enforcement officers who are watching your show right now, who put their uniform on to protect our fellow Americans, to make our communities safer, this president supports you, and he loves you. Look at our economy. It is booming again, thanks to the pro-growth, less regulatory policies of this administration. And we just signed, President Trump just signed the most significant piece of tax legislation in American history, the largest tax cut.  For working and middle class families, that means more money directly into the pockets of every single American watching your show tonight. You look at what he's done to root out DEI and waste, fraud and abuse in our federal government to keep men out of women's sports. Victory upon victory. We had another one.  with the Supreme Court today handing another big victory to not just the Trump administration, but more importantly, parents and students and families across the country. The Supreme Court saying that, yes, Secretary of Education Lyndon McMahon can move forward with the president's promise to dismantle the Department of Education, return education back to parents, back to states, so we can have the best, brightest, most highly educated students in the world.  win after win every day. We will continue to work hard. And I just want to say to your audience, there is not a more hardworking president than Donald J. Trump. I witness it with my own two eyes every day. That man is working around the clock. He hardly ever sleeps. He's constantly thinking about not just the problems in our country here, but around this world and how to solve them. And look at what he's done on the world stage with bringing peace to the Middle East,  withdrawing Russia and Ukraine to actually talk directly for the first time in this war in years. We see what's happening with the hostages coming out of Gaza, and he's going to keep pushing until every last hostage is out. This is a president who is a peacemaker-in-chief, and it cannot be overstated how successful the first six months of this administration have been, thanks to the leadership of President Trump.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Caroline, let me read a headline from the Washington Examiner. Trump's tariffs deregulation give June its first budget surplus in 20 years. Wow. That's not gotten a lot of attention.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: No, it hasn't. And all of the naysayers, all of the so-called economic experts who doubted this president and his economic formula are now eating their words. In fact, there was a story on the cover of the Wall Street Journal today saying that those fears of recession that everyone was ranting and raving about have now cooled because the economy and everyone from Wall Street to Main Street understands this is a president who is a businessman and he knows what he's doing.  pro-growth, higher wages, less inflation, less taxes, and more money back in people's pockets. And look at the investments that have poured into our country. We have companies all over the world who are coming to build factories and create jobs with American hands and American labor right here in the United States of America. This is the best country on the planet to do business in. And that's something President Trump  promised the American worker. I was with him on the campaign. I know you covered it, Sean. When he traversed this country and promised the American worker, he was going to stand up for them. And his economic agenda has surely done that. And all of the so-called experts, they have been proven wrong. The president knows what he's doing. He wants to bring growth back to this country.  He wants to end the Bidenflation crisis, and he already has in just six months. There's more work to do. He will continue to do it. But he has a proven economic formula that works. Just look at the success of his first term as president.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Let me ask you about the 700 percent increase of attacks on ICE agents. Add to that the doxing of ICE agents and their families. Now, the president did pull the plug on free tuition for illegals, and the president did authorize ICE agents to protect themselves when rocks are being thrown at them by protesters, and protect themselves by whatever means is necessary.  And then you have the L.A. mayor, Karen Bass, announcing a new cash giveaway plan for Biden illegals. How is it possible that you're going to give away free money to illegals? And in New York state, they're talking about hiring attorneys for illegals. And then you have sanctuary state and city policies. How is any of this not against the law? How is it not aiding and abetting lawbreaking?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: The Democrats have completely lost their minds, and they have forgotten the number one reason they lost the election in an overwhelming fashion on November 5th. And it's because they were putting American citizens behind illegal aliens who were invading our country for four years. You think about the images outside of the Roosevelt Hotel in New York, which was once a historic landmark hotel where presidents used to go  to hang out and host meetings. It has now been run into the ground. It is now a desolate place where millions of illegal aliens invaded cities like New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles. They stole the benefits that should be going to hard-working, tax-paying Americans, and they committed crimes all across this country, and many American lives have been lost.  So now the president has empowered federal law enforcement to actually do the jobs they signed up to do to remove these public safety threats from our communities. And it is shameful that you have elected leaders who are elected to protect their American citizen constituents.  who are aiding and abetting this violence against federal law enforcement. You look at Los Angeles and the raid that ICE just conducted on a marijuana facility. Three hundred illegal criminals were pulled out of that facility, some of them unaccompanied minors. By the way, the Biden administration lost thousands of children that this administration is focused on finding with law enforcement operations like these. And there was also child predators and convicted murderers.  who were picked up in that operation as well. God bless the men and women of ICE. They are heroes. And they are great men and women who put on that uniform every day and deserve to go home safely to their families at night. And the Democrats who are allowing this violence to take place against them should be ashamed of themselves. And I know that the American people will firmly reject that position in the next election, just like they did in the previous election on November 5th, when they reelected President Trump and the Trump administration to seal our border  and deport illegal criminals from our homeland.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We saw the reaction the president got at MetLife Stadium. Not exactly a red state, to say the least, this weekend. Caroline Levitt, thank you. The Hannity White House briefing. We appreciate your time.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The host (SEAN HANNITY) initiates the discussion by acknowledging the Trump administration's accomplishments and questions if they will be celebrated. He then shifts the focus to various critical topics such as the budget surplus, attacks on ICE agents, sanctuary city policies, and the treatment of illegal immigrants. The host also highlights the President's reception at MetLife Stadium.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Caroline Leavitt, the White House Press Secretary, defends and praises the Trump administration's actions. She underscores various achievements, including securing the border, supporting law enforcement, implementing economic growth policies, and signing significant tax legislation. She also criticises Democratic policies on immigration, arguing they prioritise illegal immigrants over American citizens and endanger public safety. Leavitt emphasises the President's hard work and leadership.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation is a White House briefing where Press Secretary Caroline Leavitt highlights the Trump administration's achievements in its first six months. She emphasises policy successes, economic growth, and border security. The host also touches on controversial issues related to immigration, sanctuary cities, and the treatment of ICE agents, criticising Democratic policies.

video_title: How rent control laws 'hurt' housing

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It is official, former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo releasing a video on X minutes ago saying he is back in the race for New York City mayor. He will run as an independent candidate after getting crushed in the Democratic primary by Democratic Socialist Zoran Mamdani. Mamdani, who won the primary with a decisive 12-point victory, champions a citywide rent freeze on rent-stabilized units.  a call that has rattled landlords, real estate interests and even some economists ahead of November's mayoral election. Jeff Green is a self-made billionaire real estate entrepreneur with holdings in New York, Palm Beach and all around the country. He first experienced rent control while attending Harvard Business School when he purchased a home in Somerville, Massachusetts. Because if I recall right, Jeff, you couldn't afford the dorms. So you bought a kind of a rundown building. You thought, oh, maybe I'll just  by the building and it was really cheap and then you found that you were dealing with rent stabilization, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, no, it wasn't that I couldn't afford the dorm but I didn't get into the good apartment complex so I bought a three-decker to live in and at the time the city of Somerville  we've had rent control. And it was actually voted out while we were there, which is a very brave move for the alderman. Remember, when I was at Harvard Business School, I took a course at the Kennedy School, and I wrote a paper on rent control in 1978. And I had looked at all kinds of research that had shown that rent control laws absolutely do nothing but hurt housing and housing prices and rents. And it's almost 50 years later, we're still talking about doing this, coming up with using this, which we know is ineffective.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Tell me and tell our viewers why rent freezes don't work. Because let's just say I am one of the many people, because the voters spoke in this primary, who can't afford to live in New York, or they're really, really stressed by the high rent payments, who say, well, wait a minute. Rent freeze sounds good. I should be able to have a decent job and pay my rent. Explain why it works in the reverse.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I mean, look, you were talking about making mortgage payments with Ancor in your last segment. I'm sure you'd love to have your mortgage frozen the rest of your life. I mean, I'd like to have my mortgage payment frozen, my insurance payment frozen. Everyone would rather have all their expenses frozen.  But the reality is that right now we have a New York City and a lot of cities in the country have housing shortages. So how do you solve a housing shortage is by creating more housing. You're not going to create more housing by making it so unappealing to developers to build housing. And that's what's exactly what's happened in New York. I have three projects in New York. We have one in Hudson Square, which is kind of just between Tribeca and West Village.  We have a waiting list there. Every time we get a notice for someone to move out, there's another tenant paying higher rent lined up for that apartment. What is that saying to me? It's saying there's a huge housing shortage in New York City. We need, so, look, I'm all in favor. We're a wealthy country. If somebody has a hardship, they're elderly, they're disabled, and they can't afford housing, as a country, we should offer that subsidies. And that's why we have Section 8 programs for people who legitimately, hopefully legitimately,  have hardships. But to just freeze rents across the board all you're doing is completely discouraging any investor or developer from investing in markets that are desperate to get new housing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Who would you consider financially backing? You are not a New York resident, obviously, but you have properties here. Cuomo just announced via a thing on X, a video on X, that he's in. There's Mayor Eric Adams, who is also running as an independent because he didn't win the Democratic primary. And it's almost like the Hunger Games at this point.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, look, I mean, they're both better choices. I mean, I get what Mondami is doing. I mean, he's trying to appeal to people by giving away something free. I'm going to freeze your rent if you vote for me. And the most voters, you know, would rather have frozen rents. Who wouldn't want their rent frozen? I understand. But policymakers should not be doing these cheap programs, which is really take advantage of  of the desperation and how scared people are about their rents. Because what you're really doing is you're going to cause their kids aren't going to ever be able to afford to live in New York. Because who's going to build a new building when these cities just keep freezing rents and keep taking away the income of those who are invested in this city?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: What is the number one thing that you wish you could see from New York City and the government here that would inspire more building?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, it's very simple. How do you get more building? Zoning is one thing. You know, if you increase, if you give people zoning incentives to get, you know, more housing, if you are on a lot, you know, maybe higher, higher, higher areas, ratios, higher density. Look, in the state of Florida, we have a workforce program now where the state actually has gone in and overridden every city zoning law.  and said that if you build 40% of more workforce housing in any city in Florida, you can build the highest height allowed within a mile of the building, unless it's next to a residential neighborhood, the highest height. And the double, one and a half times the highest floor area ratio.  And so what they're saying is, we want workforce housing. We want affordable housing in Florida. So we're going to make it so appealing to real estate developers and investors that we're going to give them a chance to make some money. The other side of that is, there's no property tax at all on that 40% of workforce housing. So they've made it so appealing, you're going to see even more housing built in Florida. New York has to start thinking the same way. Otherwise,  Everyone in New York is going to move to Florida, which is great for someone like me, who's a big investor there, but pretty tough in New York.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Jeff, it's good to see you. And you have real world experience with all of these situations. So we really appreciate it. Thank you for coming on.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer introduces the topic of Andrew Cuomo entering the New York City mayoral race as an independent. They ask Jeff Green about his views on rent freezes, highlighting the appeal of rent freezes to voters struggling with high rent payments but also the potential concerns raised by landlords and economists. The interviewer also probes Green about his financial backing for the mayoral candidates and his suggestions for inspiring more building in New York City.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Jeff Green opposes rent freezes, citing his research and personal experience with rent control in Somerville, Massachusetts. He argues that rent freezes create housing shortages by discouraging developers from investing in new housing projects. Green believes that to address the housing shortage, cities should create more housing supply through incentives like zoning changes and tax breaks. He suggests that providing subsidies for individuals with hardships is a more targeted approach to addressing affordability issues than freezing rents across the board.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the potential impact of a citywide rent freeze in New York City proposed by the Democratic Socialist candidate Zoran Mamdani. The interviewer speaks with Jeff Green, a billionaire real estate entrepreneur, who argues against rent freezes based on his personal experiences and economic research.

video_title: America cannot become healthy again without the cooperation of US industry, says RFK Jr.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I spoke a few little bit ago with Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and Secretary of Health and Human Services Robert Kennedy Jr. on how to make America healthy again. Please take a listen.  All right, it's a big news day, but not only international and foreign policy in Ukraine and Russia, but also on the health side, very important. And joining me now, Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Thanks to both of you. I appreciate it very, very much.  Mr. Kennedy, Secretary Kennedy, you'll be doing everybody a great favor. We will owe you a real debt of gratitude if you can get these petroleum-based dyes or other dyes out of the kids' diets, out of the schoolchildren's diets, and actually out of the adult diets, too. Can you do it, sir?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, and you know, Larry, when we came in six months ago and we said we're going to get rid of the nine petroleum-based synthetic dyes that are in our food that cause ADHD, that are associated with cancers and all kinds of a grim inventory of other health injuries, people laughed and they said we'd never be able to do it. But what happened today, which is the dairy industry has now made a commitment  to get rid of all dyes by the end of 2026. And some of them are already taking action. Some of them have already gotten rid of the dyes. We now have, with this contribution, with this commitment, we now have about 40 percent of the food industry that's already made that commitment. And 35 percent of the food industry was already, had already gotten rid of the dyes.  We're very proud of this public-private partnership. I'm very grateful for our partnership with Brooke and with our partnership with the industry. We cannot make America healthy again.  without the cooperation of the American farmers and American industry. And they are stepping up to the plate. And we're very grateful to them.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And, you know, Mr. Kennedy, I was listening to Marty McCary last night, your FDA commissioner, obviously, talk about why it is that these kids now, kids growing up, are in such lousy health.  And it has so much to do with what they're being fed. And this dye business, petroleum-based dye, even in ice cream, I got to tell you, I didn't know it was in ice cream until I read up on what you all were saying. I mean, it's really quite remarkable, but there's got to be an urgency to it, a real urgency to it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: There's urgency and, you know, FDA also is stepping up to the plate. We've already approved Fast-Track and approved in the last two months three new vegetable-based dyes. Today, we approved a new vegetable-based dye, Blue Dye.  You know, we're going to make sure that these companies and this industry has the supply chains so that they're able to get the products that they need to continue to meet the needs of their consumers, but in a way that keeps our children healthy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And Madam Secretary, Brookie Rollins, my dear friend, it's up to you, I guess, to implement this with respect to what food stamps and school lunches and other things.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, that's right. And listen, this partnership we talk about a lot is unprecedented, never before in American history. Do you have an HHS secretary who is just simpatico? We talk almost daily, working together to make America healthy again. Bobby Kennedy understands more than anyone that you can't do that without American agriculture and the American farmer. Our announcement today outside on USDA steps, but to your point, Larry, USDA spends $400 million every single day on our nutrition programs, SNAP,  I mean, this is a market mover in terms of what weíre feeding America. So being able to ensure that our farmers, especially some of our smaller farmers, have the market in which to sell their locally homegrown produce, but also working with the big  dairy producers, the ice cream makers, all of the above, to get the healthiest, best choices out into America. But especially as you're talking about, Larry, you know, three out of our four kids couldn't pass the military readiness test today. Something has to change. And Secretary Kennedy is leading the way, and we here at USDA are here to support him in every way we can.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So just to make it clear, I mean,  Can you get waivers and or change legislation, or was anything in the one big beautiful bill that would stop this? You know, food stamps, SNAP, school lunches, et cetera, et cetera. You know, you're the Lord High Executioner. He's the information guy on this. You're the Lord High Executioner. Can you execute this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I have to say I have never been called the Lord High Executioner before, Larry, but I love you so much. Listen, to your point, yes, USDA, and we have been working with some of our best governors across the country, Arkansas, Indiana,  Iowa, Idaho, Tennessee, et cetera, et cetera, to get the waivers put into place so that taxpayer dollars through SNAP are no longer buying sugary drinks and junk food, which is what a lot of the populations that rely on these food stamps, that was the number one purchase within the food stamp program was sugary drinks, $13 billion of about $110 billion program. That is unsustainable.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Secretary Kennedy, just on a related matter, but somewhat distant.  The former president of Harvard University, Larry Summers, who was Treasury Secretary under Bill Clinton—I'm sure you know Summers—Secretary under Bill Clinton, when they moved, they had great reforms on welfare. They moved from welfare to workfare. He's out there saying in The New York Times and elsewhere that the Medicaid reforms, the eligibility reforms for able-bodied, will cause 100,000 people to die.  I mean, I think that's an outrageous, outrageous claim, Secretary Kennedy. What's your take on that? Can you fight back on that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: First of all, there's no cuts on Medicaid. There is a, there's a diminishment of the growth rate of Medicaid, which is bankrupting our country. And by the way,  The national debt is also a determinant, a social determinant of health. If we're leaving our kids with these giant debts, they can't afford health care. They can't afford good food. In 1996, when Larry Summers was working for President Clinton,  they put in the TRAMP program, they put in a work requirement, and it was regarded as one of the most successful poverty diminishment programs in the entire Clinton administration. Oh, you know, in recent years, Obamacare included, Medicaid was designed, Larry, for people who were poor, for children, for mothers,  And it was expanded during the Obamacare to include able-bodied Americans, and the growth rate went way up. The hospital services and doctor services are no longer available for the target population.  This is not a good outcome, and we're bankrupting the states. It's the biggest expense for all of our states. They're all going bankrupt. We've got to do something to fix it. And luckily, we have a president who's willing to do that. We're not going to cut Medicaid, and there's nobody who's going to die from this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think Summers has a very bad case of amnesia, and I'm glad you pointed out the fiscal side of it. Madam Secretary, last one to you. Have you figured out a solution to the immigrant workers, the illegal immigrant workers in the travel industry, the hotel industry, meatpacking, farm? What's going to happen here, Brookie?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, the President has been unequivocal in, A, his support of no amnesty, mass deportation. If you've broken the law, you've broken the law, while at the same time saying we have to do everything we can to protect our farmers and our farm workers. Secretary Lori Chavez de Rimmer, one of our colleagues from the Cabinet who is really, really great, has opened up an Office of Immigration Policy over at Labor. She is really looking to solve this very, very quickly.  Ultimately, we have to move to a 100 percent American workforce. Now, a lot of this, Larry, I think you can appreciate, can be solved through automation. We are looking at that very closely and working with a lot of our great farmers around the country, but also ensuring we have got so many job openings in America. It actually may even go back to what Secretary Kennedy was talking about, the able-bodied men and women in America who are not working today. Now, will they be filling all of the farm openings? No, probably not.  But this idea of dignity of work, Larry, you and I talked about a lot in the first Trump term. It's time to return to that theme and that great righteous vision of every man and woman in America having a job and having the ability to provide for their families. So there are a lot of solutions on the table, and we're moving forward.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right. Secretary Kennedy, we appreciate it very much, sir. Secretary Rollins, we appreciate it very, very much. We'll talk some more on all this. Thank you for coming on.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you, Larry.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Secretary Brooke Rollins underscores the importance of public-private partnerships in achieving health goals. She highlights the USDA's role in implementing changes through nutrition programs like SNAP and school lunches. Secretary Rollins discusses working with farmers and states to obtain waivers and ensure healthier food options are available. She also addresses the issue of illegal immigrant workers in agriculture, emphasising the need for a 100% American workforce while exploring solutions like automation and leveraging able-bodied American workers.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. emphasises the harmful effects of petroleum-based dyes in food, particularly on children's health. He highlights the industry's commitment to removing these dyes by 2026 and the FDA's approval of vegetable-based dyes as alternatives. Secretary Kennedy also defends Medicaid reforms, stating they aim to control growth rates without cuts, and emphasises the fiscal responsibility of such measures.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The host (possibly Larry Elder) expresses support for the administration's efforts to remove artificial dyes from food and emphasises the urgency of the issue. He also discusses the broader implications of food quality on public health, particularly among children. The host questions the implementation of these changes in programs like SNAP and school lunches. He also touches on Medicaid reforms, criticising claims that they will lead to significant health harm, and brings up the topic of illegal immigrant workers in various industries, seeking solutions that protect farmers while upholding the law.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the administration's efforts to improve public health through dietary changes and regulatory reforms. They focus on removing petroleum-based dyes from food, promoting vegetable-based alternatives, and utilising public-private partnerships to achieve these goals. The conversation also touches on broader health-related issues like Medicaid reforms, immigration policies affecting the agricultural industry, and the importance of a dignified workforce.

video_title: New UFO research found unidentified object with significance: Professor | Elizabeth Vargas Reports

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: In order to solve the biggest mysteries of our universe, there need to be scientists willing to study them. But the stigma surrounding UFOs has discouraged generations of researchers from taking a closer look at the age-old question, are we alone? Well, now that's all changing, as real scientists with real degrees and real academic credentials are taking on the topic. A group of scientists just published a paper about how to scientifically study UFOs, and they've done their own field work to show how it's done.  They say most of the UFOs they have studied on camera were man-made things, like drones or helicopters. But there was one, they say, that they couldn't figure quite what it was. So what was it? Joining us now is University of Albany physics professor Matthew Zydagas, who published this research. All right, so tell us more. How did you go about doing this, and what did you find?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, we had the focus of having an instrumented field study for UAP. So it's not the first, but what we've done is we've published our work in the highest impact factor journal to ever carry a paper on this topic. So while we don't have  some kind of final conclusive smoking gun evidence of something anomalous. What we've done is really help break down the stigma and the taboo by publishing our results in a major journal, Progress in Aerospace Sciences.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So you were able to identify most of the objects, but one you could not. What do you think that was? Can you describe what properties it had?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That's right. So we found one dark spot with white dots in it in one of our camera systems. Now, by itself, that could be anything. It could be a camera artifact or glitch. But it seemed to have some correspondence.  at least to a small degree of statistical significance with an ionizing radiation event and with Doppler weather radar data hits using publicly available National Weather Service and NOAA data. So again, not conclusive statistically, but the strange hint that there was something physical in the sky and that it wasn't just a camera glitch at the time.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: When was this?  Like when did that happen?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: This was in July of 2021. So I went with a group called UAPX and we were part of a documentary film called A Tear in the Sky.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And just very quickly, you started to get interested in this because of the infamous 2004 Tic Tac video from the USS Nimitz. That's what sort of sparked your interest in all this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So, that kind of solidified my interest, but I already had interest much earlier from childhood, growing up watching Unsolved Mysteries and shows, you know, like that with Robert Stack, and seeing all the famous cases like the Cash Landrum and Rendersome Forest incident. And I just thought there's all these famous cases, even before 2004, that I found the evidence compelling that there was a there there, that there was something to study and try to understand.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And it's worth noting, we still don't know what that video, the tic-tac video, that's still a sort of unexplained mystery. The pilots who saw that in the sky are convinced it was something otherworldly. Matthew Shadagas, fascinating. Come back and tell us more when you have more, but it's fascinating and it's a great step forward for scientists to be studying this as well. Appreciate it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you so much.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer probes Professor Zydagas about the study's methods, findings, and the unexplainable object. They express interest in the implications of the research and its potential to change public perception of UFOs. The interviewer also asks about the timing of the incident and the inspiration behind Professor Zydagas's interest in the field.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Professor Zydagas explains that the study involved an instrumented field study for Unidentified Aerial Phenomena (UAPs) and was published in a prestigious journal to enhance credibility. He describes the unexplainable object as a dark spot with white dots, associated with ionising radiation events and Doppler weather radar data hits. Professor Zydagas emphasises the statistical significance of these findings but acknowledges their inconclusiveness. He also mentions his long-standing interest in UFOs, sparked by childhood curiosity and various famous cases, and notes that the infamous 2004 Tic Tac video solidified his determination to pursue scientific research in this area.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a scientific study on UFOs conducted by a group of researchers led by Professor Matthew Zydagas. The study aims to break down the stigma surrounding UFO research and presents a methodological approach to investigating these phenomena. The researchers conducted fieldwork and analysed data, identifying most UFOs as man-made objects but finding one unexplainable anomaly.

video_title: 'There is no client list': Jeffrey Epstein's former lawyer | Cuomo

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Is the government hiding a client list or anything that the Trump administration could release tonight?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: No, there is no client list. There never has been a client list. A client list suggests that Jeffrey Epstein made a list of people to whom he trafficked women. What there is, is a redacted FBI affidavit  from accusers, there are several of them, from accusers that accuse Jeffrey, that accuse various people of having improper sex. And that has been redacted. The names of the people accused have been blacked out. Now, of course, because I was the lawyer and I did all the investigations, I know who all these people are. I could figure out, based on everything that  I saw who Mr. X is, Mr. Y is, and Mr. Z. I can tell you right now, none of them are public figures who are currently in office. Some of them were previously in office. Some of them are dead. But there is no client list.  And the redactions could be undone if you go to court. So, many of the things that are being suppressed are being suppressed by two judges in Manhattan. And they're doing it largely to protect the alleged accusers, who are, in the view of the judges, victims, even though we don't know what their actual status is, but the judges have  issued orders, which is why I can't disclose things I'd love to disclose, saying that you can't disclose this information. But Pam Bondi and the Justice Department and Donald Trump are not responsible for that. I don't know of any information that they could disclose that they haven't disclosed. Now, maybe there is some, but I'm simply not aware of it. And so I think it's important to place the blame where the blame deserves to be placed.  The vast majority of people who are in the files—and I know them all. I've seen all the names. The vast, vast majority of them have already been disclosed. They're in articles all over the world. They're in books that have been written. So, if we got everything, everything, you would be shocked how few  Names are there that haven't already been disclosed. The media hasn't, by the way, done a good enough job in finding the people who have been disclosed in the public record. So that's that list. Then there's the videotapes. People say there must be sex tapes. I know the whole story there. There is a videotape, maybe several videotapes.  They came under the following circumstances. Before any of this happened, Epstein was robbed by one of his employees of money and of a licensed gun. And he called the Palm Beach police, and they installed video cameras, not in the bedrooms, but in the living room.  And those video cameras recorded some people, but there's no sexual allegations there. So, there's nothing to that. And then there's Tucker Carlson's absurd allegations about the Mossad. There, I know it from very, very personal experience. Why?  I was representing Jeffrey Epstein. I asked him about everything, including whether he had any contacts with intelligence agencies. If he had, he would have been dying to tell me that, because I could have used that to get him a better deal. If he had worked with the Mossad or the CIA, that would have been golden for me. But, of course, he said no. And then I checked it with my sources in Israel.  Let me clear. I once represented the Mossad. When five Israeli Mossad agents were captured in Cyprus, the head of the Mossad asked me to represent them. I did. I got them out. And the Mossad sent me a congratulatory note. I'm friendly with many of the people who have been heads of the Mossad. I'm not going to tell you who my sources are, but I can tell you with absolute certainty he had no connections to Mossad.  He only got connected to Israel very late in this when he met Ehud Barak and he made business dealings with him. But there was no connection to Mossad. The reason that story generated is because his girlfriend, Ghislaine Maxwell's father, probably did have a connection to Mossad, Robert Maxwell, but it had nothing to do with Jeffrey Epstein. And as far as the suicide is concerned,  Of course it was a suicide, but it was a suicide, I believe, assisted by jailers. It was not a suicide that he could have committed alone. I think the jailers had something to do with his cellmate being dismissed, with the cameras being turned off. So there are things that can be hidden. But there's no smoking gun here, and there's no fault on the part of this administration, as far as I can tell.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you for watching. Subscribe below and download our NewsNation app right now on your phone and you will get fact-based, unbiased news for all Americans.

summary.unstructured_summary:
{'high_level_summary': 'The conversation discusses the Jeffrey Epstein case, clarifying several misconceptions. The key points are
: there is no client list; the redacted FBI affidavit contains accusations against individuals, none of whom are current public figures; the Trump administration is not responsible for suppressing information; most names in the files have already been disclosed; there are no sex tapes involving sexual allegations; Epstein had no connections to the Mossad; and his suicide was likely assisted by jailers.', 'SPEAKER_01': 'The speaker (likely Alan Dershowitz) denies the existence of a client list. He explains that the redacted FBI affidavit contains accusations from accusers against various individuals, but none of them are current public figures. He asserts that the Trump administration and Pam Bondi are not responsible for suppressing information, which is being done by two judges in Manhattan to protect the alleged accusers. The speaker also reveals that he knows many of the names in the files and that most have already been disclosed to the public. He discusses the videotapes, clarifying that they were installed in the living room after Epstein was robbed and do not contain any sexual allegations. Additionally, he strongly denies Epstein had any connections to the Mossad, stating he would have used that information to Epstein\'s advantage in court and that he personally checked with his sources in Israel. The speaker also believes Epstein\'s suicide was assisted by jailers due to negligence in his cell security.', 'SPEAKER_00': 'The interviewer (SPEAKER_00) does not provide direct statements but guides the conversation by asking questions about the government hiding information related to the Trump administration and Jeffrey Epstein. They seem to be seeking clarity on the existence of a client list, the responsibility for suppressing information, and any potential involvement of public figures or intelligence agencies. The interviewer\'s final remarks promote their news channel, emphasising its commitment to fact-based and unbiased news.'}

video_title: Masked ICE agents afraid of 'humiliation' of going into society arresting people: Rivera | CUOMO

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Democrats are pushing legislation that would require ICE agents to remove their masks when arresting illegal migrants, or I guess arresting anyone. Why is that the focus?  Why aren't they fighting about the policies and about how the Fourth Amendment is being interpreted and the locations that are being used? Why play to the petty aspect? I'll tell you why. Because this is the BS that works on social media. The mask. Let me tell you, there's good reason and sus reason for them to wear masks. If you were getting doxxed based on what you did at work, you might be a little bit more careful about your identity also.  A sitting Democratic member of Congress wanted to dox. You know, this can be a real problem. You know, this Representative Carbajal doxed an Immigration and Customs Enforcement employee who was subsequently attacked by rioters and sent to the emergency room. That's messed up. Now, you can say, well, I think what they're doing is messed up. Fine. Let's have that fight.  Let's have that fight. Let's fight about what the policy should be. The Democrats should be involved in that, but who gives a damn about the mask?  Let's discuss. Former Acting Deputy DHS Secretary, Senior Fellow for the Center for Renewing America, Ken Cuccinelli, and NewsNation correspondent at large, Geraldo Rivera. Ken, the answer to the question, who cares about the masks, is sitting right next to you in handsome form. Geraldo Rivera cares about the masks and says, real men don't wear masks. Why do the masks matter, my friend?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, normally when police are conducting their business, you wouldn't want them wearing masks. You would want them to have their name tags on, because it's part of accountability. However, there's a balance of concerns here. And your first priority has to be the safety of your officers. If your officers aren't safe, they aren't even going to be able to do their job. And when we have  lots of different types of folks, most appallingly congressmen, but lots of different types of folks trying to dox these agents, then their safety is put at risk. And let's be real clear, Chris, this isn't just about the officers. You and I both know that what's the real threat is your family.  your family gets put at risk. And that's the implicit threat here. It isn't just the safety of officers. Officers, they take these jobs knowing that they step into danger every day, and they do it for us, and God bless them for it. But they're not putting their families on the line to do it. Well, the doxing puts their families on the line. It's really repugnant. It's awful.  And, frankly, if the case can be made connecting the doxing to the violence, then those cases should be prosecuted.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You know, listen, I get it. And believe me, if people knew what my family has been through, one, they would stone me for staying in this business. And, two, they might even have some sympathy. Yeah, I doubt it. Geraldo, what's the counterargument? What bothers you about the masks? What matters about what we're seeing with ICE enforcement policies that should be the focus?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I'm shocked that my brother disagrees with me so dramatically on this issue, Chris, because—and hello, Ken. Can you imagine a world where cops wore masks, where sheriffs wore masks, where the FBI wore masks?  where court officers wore masks. You cannot. They shouldn't. Because of the ominous danger and the wicked effect that law enforcement in masks would have on society. We would all be terrorized. And I submit to both of you that that is the reason they all wear masks. It's not the doxxing. As far as I know, there's been a handful of cases, maybe just one or two,  What they're afraid of is the humiliation of going into society and arresting otherwise law-abiding people. The statistics are out now. Over 70 percent of the people arrested so far have no criminal record.  What is going on here is horrible, and you have to give some equity to the people who are being targeted for these unprecedented sweeps that are now temporarily, at least, on pause because of a federal judge in Southern California crack.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Opposes the idea of ICE agents wearing masks, arguing it would have an ominous danger and wicked effect on society, terrorising the public. Believes that the masks are worn to avoid humiliation of arresting otherwise law-abiding people, citing statistics that over 70% of those arrested have no criminal record. Downplays the significance of doxing, mentioning only a handful of cases.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Acknowledges the importance of accountability but emphasises the priority of officer safety. Argues that doxxing puts not only officers but also their families at risk, creating an implicit threat. Suggests that cases connecting doxing to violence should be prosecuted.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Argues that the mask mandate is a distraction from the real issues like policy debates and Fourth Amendment interpretations. Highlights the safety concerns for ICE agents due to doxxing, noting an incident where an agent was attacked after being doxxed by a sitting Democratic member of Congress. Emphasises the need for a focus on substantive policy discussions rather than petty matters.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a proposed legislation by Democrats requiring ICE agents to remove their masks during arrests. The speakers debate the merits and underlying reasons for this legislation, with differing viewpoints on accountability, officer safety, and the impact on public trust.

video_title: Trump facing MAGA crises with Epstein and immigration handling: Vittert | On Balance

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: six months into his administration, Donald Trump faces now two crises. Each represents, as crises do, danger and opportunity. Tonight, Bill O'Reilly on whether Trump can solve the problems. Ambassador John Bolton on Trump's tough stance with Vladimir Putin. Plus, former AOC supporter Lucy Biggers exposes the Mamdani fantasy in New York. But first, our Wyatt Matters segment.  We've always known President Trump as a different kind of president. Six months into his administration, we are starting to see if he will be a transformational president. He faces two crises inside his own coalition, inside MAGA, Epstein and immigration.  Epstein is a crisis of confidence in the base. Immigration will test his willingness to defy the base for his legacy. As we've noted, the president has wins so far that are significant. Stock market highs, Iran strike success, tariffs now bringing in serious cash, a closed border. Establishment Washington said all of those things were impossible. But the Epstein case is unlike every other kerfuffle President Trump and his administration, Trump 2.0, have faced.  Because the handling of the Jeffrey Epstein files is not a case of MAGA vs. the media, because then MAGA can fight back against the media. And there have been a lot of made-up scandals so far in the first six months. Where was MAGA vs. the media? And MAGA's won. Just think about Signalgate. Remember? Haven't heard about that in a long time. It's gone. This is MAGA vs. MAGA, or grassroots MAGA vs. Washington MAGA. And the base right now is furious with Trump and his administration.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I will not rest until we go full Jan 6 committee on the Jeffrey Epstein files. Release the Epstein files, am I right?

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I blame Pam Bondi.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Those are fighting words, not from the left, but from Turning Point USA, which is the campus activist group that is all about Donald Trump. And Trump spent this weekend trying to defuse the crisis. He wrote on Truth Social, what's going on with my boys, and in some cases, gals? They're all going after Attorney General Pam Bondi. He's doing a fantastic job. We're on one team, MAGA, and I don't like what's happening. And then Charlie Kirk, who is the young acolyte of Donald Trump.  one of his most vocal supporters, got a phone call from Trump over the weekend. Just take a look at the difference of Charlie on Friday versus today on his radio show.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: How many of you raise your hand and think this is a big deal, the Epstein thing? Would you raise your hand? So, I mean, every hand has gone up. I'm done talking about Epstein for the time being. I'm going to trust my friends in the administration. I'm going to trust my friends in the government to do what needs to be done, solve it, balls in their hands.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And now you see the power of Donald Trump. Because all the MAGA influencer types understand that if they lose Trump, they lose their audience. The audience will not turn on Trump. The audience will turn on the influencers. Trump is MAGA. And that brings us to the next fight. If the MAGA faithful are furious over Epstein, their heads are going to positively explode over any talk or even ideas about offering amnesty to illegal immigrants.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: What do I think about amnesty for farm workers? I think it's the most grotesque thing I've ever heard. Are you joking? They all must be deported. Mass deportations now. Amnesty never. No amnesty. Repeat after me.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: No amnesty. Period. End of story. Amnesty should be the biggest slur in the entire English language. Amnesty is a repugnant word. Amnesty is disgusting because it's a slur against you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Keep in mind, Charlie Kirk is also in the never amnesty camp. Trump now must choose between keeping his base happy or taking, we talked about this over last week, his unique point in history.  concrete steps to cement his legacy as president. A comprehensive deal on immigration would do that, and amnesty, probation, parole is going to have to be part of some grand deal. But for now, the focus is on Epstein. Trump must get past it. Bill O'Reilly noted the Epstein saga could really hurt Trump's credibility. He writes the Justice Department does have information, and Attorney General Pam Bondi, as well as Attorney General Merrick Garland, should both answer general questions about the investigations. It's their responsibility to do that. President Trump should
