video_title: 'WIN-WIN': US ambassador to NATO explains why the NATO deal Trump brokered is so important

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right, great pleasure joining us now. Ambassador to NATO Mr. Matt Whitaker is a very important spot. Matt Whitaker, thank you for coming on. Tell me if I've got the story basically right and maybe you could walk us through the transfer.  NATO will be purchasing the new missiles and then will hand it over to Ukraine. But there's something, they already have some Patriot missiles and we're going to give those over. It wasn't clear to me, Matt. I don't want you to give me any state secrets, but tell us what you can tell us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, well, it's good to be with you. It's good to see you, my friend, Larry. You know, I think the first thing people need to understand is, you know, when we had the NATO summit a month ago in The Hague, you know, it's really set a new path for our European allies in Canada that are all members of NATO. And that was that no longer is the American taxpayer going to foot the bill for traditional security and defense of Europe.  You know, for 76 years, American presidents have been talking about that. Donald Trump delivered it last month. And now the next step is to make Europe pay for the defense and the support of Ukraine, which Joe Biden and, you know, some members of Congress decided that the U.S. taxpayer and the hardworking Americans should be paying for that.  Obviously, America makes the best weapons, and everyone wants them. And Ukraine, to defend themselves, President Trump's been clear, they should get access to U.S. weapons. And so Europe has come through the NATO structure and said, we'll put up the money, we'll buy these American weapons, and we'll send them to Ukraine to defend themselves.  Now, there is already a lot of support for Ukraine happening, and weapons are constantly moving, and that's anything from Patriot missiles, which you mentioned, to things like just ammunition and other types of armaments. But this idea that President Trump has put together and brokered, I think really is a big win for Ukraine.  Ukraine to defend itself, but it's also a big win for the American taxpayer. They no longer have to pay for this, but at the same time, the jobs created by creating more weapons for the Ukrainians to use, I think it's just a win-win.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: But you know what else, Matt? Look, you look at this story here. President Trump doing his best to talk to Putin, to deal with Putin, to arrange a ceasefire with Putin, etc. And Putin was playing Trump. He was playing him, right? They'd end the phone call, as Trump said today, and as First Lady Melania apparently said, you know, Putin would get off the phone and then start bombing civilian places, which is terrible. You can't play Donald Trump. Trump is going to end this kind of appeasement.  We're going to go after him with much greater force, I think, than ever before. Isn't that part of the story here? You've got the US and NATO. It looks to me like acting in concert, allied, and they're going to give Putin, certainly send Putin a message to check his grandiose ambitions. Isn't that part of this story?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, no doubt about that, Larry. And, you know, not only is it going to be the golden age of America under Donald Trump, it's also the golden age of NATO, where NATO is refocused on war fighting on Europe. And so, you know, I mean, this is a moment, I think, where everything has come together to work. But, you know, it's only come together because of Donald Trump's leadership. And, you know, being in the room today with him and Secretary General Rutte, it was very clear.  That we all understood what we were supposed to do. You know what the path forward is. And you know it's really extraordinary. But you know what you're seeing also on the continent of Europe. And you know as you know I spend most of my time over there.  What you're seeing is you're seeing countries like Germany, France, Great Britain that are doubling their defense spending, that are really stepping up to become the allies we need them to be because we cannot be everywhere at all times. And especially as it relates to the European continent and opposing Russia, that has to be taken and handled by primarily our European allies. We're still gonna be able to fly  B-2 bombers halfway across the world drop bombs and have those guys home for pizza with their families undetected. But at the same time, we need to make sure our allies are very strong. And that's what's happening. And this is the announcement today, I think, is the next step in that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, I agree. It's the first time, really, that people are going after. We are going after Putin. Putin cannot get away with this stuff. The appeasement is over. You know, you don't play Donald Trump. He is too smart and too tough. That came out today. And I think you're going to be a very busy chap. And you've got a great partner in Mark Rutte from the Netherlands. I think you've got a great partner there as well. Anyway, Matt Whitaker, Ambassador to NATO, thank you. Appreciate it. Good luck to you. Godspeed.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Good to see you, Larry. Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Ambassador Whitaker explains that NATO has decided to have Europe pay for Ukraine's defence, marking a shift from the US footing the bill. He credits former President Trump with brokering this deal, which he sees as strengthening NATO, boosting American jobs, and ensuring European allies take greater responsibility for their security.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host praises the new NATO arrangement where Europe buys US weapons for Ukraine, seeing it as a win-win for Ukraine and the American taxpayer. He also emphasises the need to end appeasement towards Putin and suggests that under Trump's leadership, the US and NATO will act more forcefully against Russia.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses NATO's new approach to funding Ukraine's defence, with Europe now purchasing US weapons, and highlights a shift in US policy towards greater European responsibility for its defence.

video_title: 'What's the point of 50 days?': Gen. Clark on Trump's Russia ultimatum | NewsNation Now

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Every Patriot missile that gets to Ukraine is a big help. And if we can get a couple more Patriot batteries there, well, that's a big help. But the Russians are flooding Ukraine with drones. So, you're not using the Patriots against drones. You're using the Patriots against enemy big missiles that are coming in. And so you need things to take out that. And, really, if you want to get rid of the drone problem and the missile problem,  you have to shoot the archer, as my friends say, not the arrows. And so that means you need long-range strike capability. And you have got to hold the line where you are, so you need small arms, you need 155-millimeter artillery rounds, and you need all of the sort of communications gear, radar gear, electronic warfare stuff that goes with it.  We don't know what's in that package that President Trump says he's going to approve, except we know there are Patriot missiles there. And that's a good thing. But how many? That's the question. And will it be enough? And then, Laura, you've got to look at the other side of it. Why 50 days? Why don't we tell Vladimir Putin, stop, stop now?  Why are we waiting 50 days? We've been talking about this for a long time. Now, if you were going to look at this in a constructive way, you'd say there's already discussions going on. I've showed you, Mr. Putin, that I'm serious on this. We're going to send weapons and a lot more weapons. So why don't you just stop your attacks tomorrow, and then we'll talk about the other details on the ceasefire? That's what a strong leader could do.  Now, what President Trump is doing is a little bit different. I know he wants to bring Russia back into the international community, so he doesn't want to offend too badly. And he's got supporters who don't support giving assistance to Ukraine. But 50 days, 50 more days of missile strikes and drones against Kyiv, 50 more days of Russian massing its forces and trying to do a breakthrough, what's the point of the 50 days?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, and let's see if the 50 days is really 50 days, right? Because we've heard deadlines before. He's laid it down. So we'll see if that sticks. I also got to ask you, because you're so familiar with the weapons that we were just talking about, but you're also familiar with the rhetoric and the tone. Because President Trump has been expressing high frustration with Russian President Putin, saying that he's not serious about a ceasefire. So let's take a listen to what he said today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I speak to him a lot about getting this thing done. And I always hang up and say, well, that was a nice phone call. And then missiles launched into Kiev and some other city. And I said, strange. And after that happens three or four times, you say, the talk doesn't mean anything.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right. So what is your reaction to that? You know, when we take a look at what he's saying, how is Putin likely to view Trump's change of heart? Or will he even consider it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I think it goes 30 percent of the way. I think it's good to announce the defensive missiles. But we're, again, playing a patty cake with Mr. Putin by giving 50 days. It's more rhetoric. It sounds OK. But what's the holdup here? We have been going for six months on this. If we mean Putin to stop, tell him to stop.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Right. So we've got the 50-day thing and then he's threatening sanctions against Russia.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Put them on. I mean, we've been talking about them for three months. The Senate has held up its bill that was ready to go because President Trump said he might put sanctions on.  So, it seems like, again, this is Washington politics. And, unfortunately, we got people dying. And people in Europe — Laura, I have to tell you, people in Europe are looking at this as this is the first of the third World War battles, because what they see is  Russian troops lining up in Belarus to go against the Baltics. They see Russian forces in Finland, opposite Finland. They see Chinese support for Russia. They see what Russia and China are trying to do to help Iran. This is not just something you can turn your back on. And so every day matters. We should tell Russia to stop and stop now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: If you were at the table, how would you advise those that are involved in this right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I think Putin's going to keep going as long as he thinks he can step on President Trump and get what he wants. So you've got to do three things. You've got to mobilize Europe and reinforce with U.S. forces in Europe and NATO.  You've got to really surge equipment into Ukraine, and you've got to tell Mr. Putin in no uncertain terms, it's over, bud. It's over.

summary.unstructured_summary:
{'high_level_summary': 'The conversation discusses the U.S. aid to Ukraine, the effectiveness of various weapons, and the proposed 50-day timeline for a ceasefire with Russia. SPEAKER_01 emphasises the need for a comprehensive approach, including long-range strike capability, to address both drone and missile threats. They criticise the 50-day deadline as too lenient and advocate for a stronger, more decisive stance against Russia. SPEAKER_02 questions the feasibility of the 50-day deadline and explores President Trump\'s rhetoric and tone towards Putin, seeking insights into how Putin might perceive Trump\'s change of heart.', 'SPEAKER_01': 'SPEAKER_01 advocates for a robust U.S. aid package to Ukraine, including long-range strike capability, small arms, artillery rounds, and communication gear. They believe that solely relying on Patriot missiles is insufficient to address the drone and missile problems effectively. SPEAKER_01 criticises the 50-day deadline for a ceasefire with Russia as too long and suggests that a stronger leader would demand an immediate stop to attacks. They emphasise the urgency of the situation, warning that every day matters and that Europe views this conflict as a potential precursor to World War III. SPEAKER_01 proposes three key actions
: mobilising Europe, reinforcing U.S. forces in Europe and NATO, and surging equipment into Ukraine.', 'SPEAKER_02': 'SPEAKER_02 focuses on the proposed 50-day timeline for a ceasefire with Russia and questions its feasibility. They explore President Trump\'s rhetoric and tone towards Putin, seeking to understand how Putin might perceive Trump\'s statements, particularly his frustration with Putin\'s lack of seriousness about a ceasefire. SPEAKER_02 highlights Trump\'s previous phone calls with Putin and how missiles were launched into Kyiv after these calls, suggesting that Putin does not take Trump\'s words seriously.'}

video_title: Hundreds of pets rescued from Texas flooding by local group | NewsNation Live

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Organizations like Austin Pets Alive are working to relocate, rescue, and reunite owners with their beloved pets. Dr. Ellen Jefferson is president of that group. Thank you so much for being with us this morning. How many pets and animals so far have you all been able to help rescue?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We are approaching about 800 animals that have been helped along the entire Guadalupe River and San Gabriel River complex. This flood is much bigger than just Kerrville.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So it's about 800 total that we've been able to help so far. Wow. And what condition are these animals arriving in?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It's a mix. So the majority of those are animals that were already in the animal shelters that exist, the government shelters that are there. And what our job is as first responders is to go in and try to move those animals out to safety as fast as possible so that they won't be euthanized to make room for the animals that are coming in for lost and found.  And so that gives those government shelters that are on the ground the capability to be able to take in animals and hold them for a stray period that's much longer during a disaster than normally seen in animal shelters. And then we also deployed thousands of people to do search and rescue on the ground and worked with families and many, many people.  animals that are being owner surrendered in the field or where family members are trying to recuperate from losing other family members and trying to find safe placement for their pets.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Have you gotten to a point where you're able to unify pets and their people parents?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yes, we have done some of that. We are working with one trailer park in particular really stands out because it's only a park of maybe seven or eight trailers, but every single person within that has extremely devastating stories.  And those stories are range from losing family members, because the family member was trying to save the rest of the people and pets in the in their trailer to people that were swept away and found many, many miles later in trees alive.  and people that got out in the nick of time that had to leave their pets behind in their trailers. And one of the most miraculous things that we've seen is that many of the pets that were left behind in trailers, not all, but many of them were found alive near the wreckage. So, you know, we're just so in awe of animals' ability to survive.  given what's been thrown at them. And of course, many were lost, hundreds, hundreds, maybe thousands, I'm sure thousands actually were lost and are deceased. But we're so thankful for those bright spots of hope where we can see pets that survived and then we can reunite them with their family.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Wow. Well, I appreciate you highlighting some of the miracles in the midst of so much devastation. I also want to highlight as well scams that are out there. And I know you guys have been dealing with them as well. What do you want people to know about those looking to take advantage of a horrible situation?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I think the biggest thing that we've seen is Venmo. Personally, that we've seen is Venmo. We do discourage people from using GoFundMe unless they are aware of, have a personal connection to the family. The Venmo fraud that we've seen is that people are adding numbers or letters to a handle for Venmo. So make sure that you go to the charity section of Venmo to select what charity. Those are verified charities.  And if you're using Venmo as a link, don't do that. Go to Venmo app and search for charities that will prevent you from giving to somebody who should not be receiving funds that you intend for organizations like ours.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, some of these groups pretending to be animal shelters. So make sure that you are on a reputable site. Doctor Jefferson, thanks for the work you and your team are doing. 800 animals rescued so far. Thank you so much.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thank you for watching. Subscribe below and download our NewsNation app right now on your phone and you will get fact-based, unbiased news for all Americans.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Dr. Jefferson reports that they have rescued approximately 800 animals. She explains their strategies to support government shelters, conduct search and rescue, and assist families surrendering pets. She shares heartwarming stories of pet survival and reunions but also acknowledges the significant losses. Dr. Jefferson warns about Venmo fraud and advises donating to verified charities through the Venmo app.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The interviewer asks questions about the number of animals rescued, their conditions, reunions with owners, and the scams occurring during the crisis.
summary.high_level_summary: Dr. Ellen Jefferson, President of Austin Pets Alive, discusses their efforts to rescue animals affected by the floods along the Guadalupe River and San Gabriel River complex. They have rescued about 800 animals, including those from shelters and during search and rescue operations. The organisation is also working to reunite pets with their owners and warns about emerging scams targeting donations.

video_title: Only 7% of Texans have flood insurance | NewsNation Now

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: As recovery and cleanup efforts continue in Central Texas following deadly flooding, it has become clear the rebuilding process will be costly. We can all see it, right? Data from FEMA shows that only 5 to 10% of homes in the hardest hit areas have flood insurance.  Hear that again, 5 to 10%, which means that many who lost everything probably aren't insured. With us is President of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, North Dakota Insurance Commissioner, John Godfrey. Thank you so much for being here today, John, because, I mean, when we watch it and we realize how much is lost, it's just devastating. And AccuWeather recently released preliminary numbers from the flash floods in Texas.  saying that it cost an estimated $8 to $22 billion in total damage and economic loss so far. So let's talk about what that means for the residents of Central Texas. And what do you think about that number? 5 to 10% have flood insurance.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Unfortunately, it's not uncommon. That exists across the country because the flood insurance program is a different program than your standard homeowner's policy, which is years and years and years ago was divorced from their standard policy and put under the federal government, the National Flood Insurance Program. And we've had a real challenge getting through to consumers to understand that if it rains where you're at, it can flood. And so having that flood insurance policy is absolutely critically important to protecting what is oftentimes your largest asset.  We've been in talk with Congress about the reauthorization or restructuring of FEMA and looking at how do we put some more money towards pre-disaster mitigation versus always paying for the post-disaster recovery. And so we're encouraged by some of the conversations that this administration's have on addressing some of these urgent needs. But the reality is a lot of consumers across the country just don't purchase a flood insurance policy, partially because they don't realize they need to have it. They may think, I live on a hill, it never floods where I'm at. We go by the old adage, if it rains where you're at, it can flood.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know what? This reminds me of when we were covering Hurricane Sandy here in New York, and this happened to a lot of people on Long Island and New Jersey. It happened all over the place, and it was it was devastating. People are still people are still trying to rebuild after that. And you know, we take a look at what Texas is dealing with. They experienced 20 weather and climate disasters in 2024, and yet when we look at the numbers, only 7% of the statewide population has this flood insurance. So why is that number so low? You mentioned how to get it, but why don't more people have it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think because they don't understand that it's not a part of their standard policy, right? And insurance is traditionally a state regulated institution or industry. And so oftentimes the state insurance commissioner will oversee these policies, but you've got this separate standalone policy and all that you need to have, which is a flood insurance policy, which again, we've been advocating for a long time to, you know, how do we get some more private flood insurance into the marketplace? It's really hard to compete in the private market when you've got an NFIP.  and even have those conversations with Congress about how do we reauthorize this program, make sure it doesn't go bankrupt and these type of pieces. It's really confusing for consumers anytime we're talking about insurance, but then when you need to go layer it on another layer, another protection policy that you need to have, it makes it a challenge. And so it's really, a good agent's worth its weight in gold to talk to them and ask the questions about what happens if it floods? Am I covered? And kind of walk through those different scenarios to make sure that again, your largest asset is protected.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right. Well, we know that this is going to be a very long road for a lot of people. Thank you for weighing in on it, Commissioner John Godfrey. Thank you very much for being here today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We'll talk again soon.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer highlights the devastating impact of flooding in Central Texas, the low flood insurance coverage (5-10%), and the estimated $8-22 billion in damage. They draw parallels with Hurricane Sandy and Texas' frequent weather disasters, emphasizing the need for flood insurance understanding.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Commissioner Godfrey explains that flood insurance is separate from standard homeowner's policies, leading to consumer confusion. He advocates for restructuring FEMA, increasing pre-disaster mitigation, and encouraging private flood insurance market participation. Godfrey emphasizes the importance of flood insurance education and the role of insurance agents.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the low flood insurance coverage in Central Texas and across the US, highlighting the financial burden of natural disasters on uninsured residents.

video_title: Trump supplying Ukraine with weapons 'great step' to fight Putin, Russia | Elizabeth Vargas Reports

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Now we're joined by Kurt Volker, former U.S. ambassador to NATO. Ambassador, great to have you here. Let's start with these weapons that President Trump approved to send to Ukraine. Ukraine urgently needs these Patriot missile defense systems, and only the U.S. has them. Axios reports the U.S. will send $10 billion worth of weapons to NATO, which will give them to Ukraine. Is that enough for the Ukrainians?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, it's a great step. It's a great start. It's essential that we eliminate the uncertainty about the availability of American weapons and ammunition for Ukraine. For the last five months, it's been very unclear would we approve these kinds of sales to Ukraine or not. Now it's clear we're willing to do it. They're going to move. This is very significant. It's a signal to Putin that  We have the ability and the will to do this, which means that his military effort is ultimately not going to succeed.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, Putin thinks he has the momentum right now in this fight.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I don't know about that. I think he's trying to grab what he can while he still can. He knows that his finances are under stress. He's having trouble recruiting the new people into the military that he wants to recruit, given the level of casualties that they have had. The economy is in bad shape, and people in Russia are impatient with that. So I think he's actually escalating in order to create an appearance of strength  and to grab what he can. But I think he also knows he's going to have to settle for a ceasefire at some point.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Trump also announced these sanctions, 100% sanctions on Russia in 50 days if Russia doesn't agree to a ceasefire. And most notably here, the secondary sanctions, sanctions on countries like India and China, because we don't really trade with Russia. That's what's going to hit them hard.  These 100% sanctions are much less than the bill in the Senate, which has widespread support, which calls for 500% sanctions. What do you make of the decision by President Trump to impose just 100% sanctions and to wait 50 days to do it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think, first off, on the 50-day warning, I think he wants a deal. He wants Putin to stop the war. So he's actually trying to create the leverage and create the opportunity for Putin to actually stop it. He's also trying to tell countries like China and India  You have 50 days to figure this out. You go tell Putin to stop the war, because if he doesn't, you're going to pay 100 percent tariffs on the goods that you're shipping to the United States, and you don't want to do that. So go tell Putin to stop the war. And if they can't convince Putin,  then they need to make alternative arrangements for energy supplies. So it puts a little bit of pressure on everybody. And I think that's the intent that Trump has in this, is not necessarily to follow through, but rather to create the incentives for everybody to solve this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: But will it? Because we've seen President Trump threaten big tariffs on practically the entire world and then back down from his own threats and his own deadlines.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, that's the key question. And in the case of Iran, on day 61, Israel launched massive attacks on Iran. The U.S. followed through. And now we have a peace deal between Israel and Iran. In the case of Putin, Trump put out two-week deadlines in the past, only to renew them with another two weeks and another two weeks. So we have to see if this 50-day deadline really sticks. But I think this combination of things  steady supply of arms for Ukraine, secondary sanctions that can dry up the funds going to the Kremlin's war budget, possibly lend lease for Ukraine, if the Congress were to approve that, where we lend money to Ukraine, they buy American weapons, they pay us back later, and then possibly seizing the frozen Russian assets from the central bank that are in both the U.S. and Europe. In the U.S., it's only $8 billion, but in Europe, it's $260 plus.  for a lot of money. If we would do that, that's a lot of money. And it could pay for a lot of financial support and a lot of weapons for Ukraine that Russia would end up paying for.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So these are things to put on the table to really get Vladimir Putin thinking about, does he really want to continue the war?

summary.SPEAKER_01: The interviewer questions the sufficiency of U.S. aid to Ukraine, highlights Putin's perceived momentum, and enquires about the effectiveness of Trump's proposed sanctions and deadlines.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Ambassador Volker views the U.S. weapons approval as a significant step. He believes Putin is escalating due to internal pressures but will eventually need to settle for a ceasefire. He analyses Trump's sanctions strategy, suggesting it aims to create leverage on China and India to influence Putin, though he acknowledges Trump's history of backing down from threats.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the U.S. approval to send weapons to Ukraine, the potential impact of sanctions on Russia, and Putin's strategy in the war.

video_title: MAGA influencers scored 'massive own goal' with Epstein: Rich Lowry | Elizabeth Vargas Reports

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Colby, Trump is begging his supporters to, quote, stop wasting time talking about Epstein, but you write today that for years Epstein was the go-to boogeyman for Trump allies looking to smear Democrats. You say Epstein isn't a side note, he's the inciting incident.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Right. He didn't just beg them. He demanded them. The Saturday night social media tweet that he put out basically said, stop, like, cut it out. And a lot of it was reaction to the stuff that you played earlier with Megyn Kelly and Tucker Carlson and Laura Ingraham. These are loyal Trump supporters that are basically calling BS on how this story has unfolded.  And so it's become this fascinating political media story. I don't think it's a boogeyman. I think it's a Frankenstein, this old Frankenstein monster that you create to terrorize everyone else. Suddenly, Frankenstein turns and terrorizes its own village. So it's fascinating to see for the first time kind of a significant split between the MAGA base and Trump with this conspiracy, Frankenstein. Will it last? I don't know. I'm popping popcorn. It's fascinating to watch unfold.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Rich, is your head spinning as much as mine is at the specter of Hakeem Jeffries allied and saying the same thing, not allied, maybe just repeating some of the same talking points that we hear Tucker Carlson and Megyn Kelly saying at the Young Conservatives Convention?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, this is such a wonderful opportunity for Democrats. You could sense the glee underlying what Jeffries was saying there. This is a massive un-goal by mega-influencers. They got spun up and got wrapped around the axle of their own conspiracy theory.  And one thing to be on the outside and saying, we need all this information, there might be some deep, dark secrets there. It's another thing, as apparently Pam Bondi did, to play it up when you're actually the sitting Attorney General of the United States, to release those white binders that you showed just a minute ago, to seem to say, she kind of says she was misinterpreted now, but seem to suggest you had the client list sitting literally on your desk, and then turn around and say, never mind. Of course, that's going to raise questions.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It raises a lot of questions because Pam Barnes is very smart and she would not, I mean, what is she talking about this file being on her desk and then all of a sudden there's no such thing as the file. Rich Tucker Carlson is now warning very darkly, quote, I feel like we're at a dangerous point now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, look, Trump is the center of the MAGA movement. People may be upset with him. They may not let this go over the medium or long term. Does that mean they're fundamentally going to break with him and turn on him? No. He is the center of things. And this will not affect his approval rating. This will not affect his general standing with the Republican Party. There'll be a lot of noise about it. But at the end of the day, he is the entirety  of the show. No one else matters. No influencer matters. No other media outlet matters compared to the massive influence of Donald Trump himself.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Colby, explain why this particular story about Jeffrey Epstein is so important to these MAGA supporters. Why are so many convinced that there is this deep state conspiracy? What's happening?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I think it starts with a deep sort of distrust of government and sort of the deep state and sort of intel operations that blackmail people. And it also ties into some sort of darker and sort of more bonkers conspiracy theories like QAnon, like there's this massive hetero strain, right? And so I think Rich is right. I don't think that this is really going to cost Trump a ton.  A large majority of the MAGA banks really do believe that this is a very important issue, is holding people to account. And they were led to believe by Dan Bongino and Kash Patel and Pam Bondi that there was going to be very powerful political figures and powerful people's influence.  taken away in handcuffs and so the problem with the conspiracy theory is that people don't take no for an answer because when you say there's no there they just assume you're covering it up right and so there's no way to win they've painted themselves into a corner and that's why it's going to be a fascinating thing to see unfold.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You were going to say Rich?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, no, that's exactly right. Every denial, no matter how sincere or perhaps plausible, just seems as though it's part of the conspiracy. But look, I mean, the Justice Department just doesn't release files on people it's not going to charge. And there may be disturbing information in there, damaging information. Sincerely, there also may be people's reputations that might be destroyed because they're incidentally mentioned in something that's totally randomly. So if you're going to charge someone in the Justice Department, you charge them.  Otherwise, you should shut up.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And the big problem here is Pam Bondi did not honor that rule.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The final speaker emphasises the rule that the Justice Department doesn't release files on non-charged individuals, criticising Pam Bondi for not honouring this rule.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Colby sees the Epstein theory as a "Frankenstein" that has turned against Trump. He notes the distrust of government within the MAGA base that fuels this theory and how it ties into QAnon. Colby believes this won't significantly cost Trump support as believers won't accept denials.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Rich views this as an opportunity for Democrats but emphasises Trump's centrality to the MAGA movement. He argues that denials only reinforce the conspiracy theory and highlights Pam Bondi's mishandling of the situation, which raised questions. Rich believes Trump's approval rating will remain unaffected.
summary.SPEAKER_03: The moderator highlights the surprising alignment between Hakeem Jeffries and MAGA commentators on this issue. They also point out Tucker Carlson's warnings and Pam Bondi's contradictory statements, noting the difficulty in debunking conspiracy theories.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the split between Trump and some MAGA supporters over the Epstein conspiracy theory, the political implications for Democrats, and the persistence of conspiracy theories despite denials.

video_title: Congress moves to redraw $3.7 trillion crypto market rules, opening door to Wall Street

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, meantime, Bitcoin jumping to an all-time high today, right now trading around $120,000 per Bitcoin. Joining me now to explain this move and the optimism around crypto week is our Mackenzie Segalos. Mackenzie.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Hey John, so even with a bit of profit taking, Bitcoin is still trading at double its level from a year ago and Ether actually outpacing it this week of about 20% and holding that key $3,000 threshold. The strength is broad based with all coins like Solana and XRP gaining ground. Now part of the move is technical.  U.S. Bitcoin ETFs pulled in $2.7 billion last week, and with options expiring and short sellers squeezed, the runway's clear for more upside. Open interest in Bitcoin futures just hit a record above $86 billion, according to Coinglass. And Ethereum open interest is near record highs as well. Both are a sign of real conviction. And now there's a policy tailwind. It's crypto week on Capitol Hill with the House weighing three bills.  one to regulate stablecoins, another to draw the line between commodities and securities, potentially further loosening the SEC's grip, and then a third to ban a Fed-issued digital dollar. Now, that market structure bill could finally bring the regulatory clarity that Wall Street's been waiting for, and markets are racing to price it in, John.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: a lot  rally later, and now at those all-time highs, I wonder if there's any chatter out there in the crypto community about the extent to which crypto is moving along with the GOP agenda.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Absolutely. I mean, you have only to look at the upside that we're seeing pegged to what's going on in Capitol Hill this week to see that. And part of that is because until now, asset managers, banks and trading platforms have mostly stayed out of crypto because the SEC kept suing over what counts as a security versus a commodity. And the Clarity Act, which is being considered this week by the House,  directly addresses that. It defines who regulates what, giving the CFTC jurisdiction over digital commodities like Bitcoin and possibly Ether, while narrowing what counts as a security under the SEC's domain. And that's the kind of legal line that compliance teams have been begging for. And that's why we're seeing a lot of upside and so much momentum going into this week specifically.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Asks about Bitcoin's rally and its connection to the GOP agenda, specifically the potential impact of proposed crypto regulations on market participation.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Explains Bitcoin's price increase, attributing it to technical factors like U.S. Bitcoin ETFs inflows, record open interest in futures, and the squeeze on short sellers. She also highlights the significance of Crypto Week on Capitol Hill, where three bills are being considered, with the Clarity Act potentially providing regulatory clarity, attracting Wall Street, and boosting crypto prices.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses Bitcoin's all-time high and the factors driving its surge, including technical aspects, institutional investments, and policy developments during Crypto Week on Capitol Hill.

video_title: Secondary sanctions on Russia will create 'great deal of backlash', says fmr. Sec. of Commerce

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Now, let's take a global view again. As we mentioned, the president announcing tariffs on the EU and Mexico this weekend, but not many of the letters he has sent or the threats he has made have translated yet into signed deals. Joining me now to discuss is Carlos Gutierrez, former Commerce Secretary and former Kellogg CEO. He's currently executive chairman at Empath and a CNBC contributor. Carlos, Secretary, welcome.  What do you make particularly of this latest move regarding Russia, the 100 percent tariff threat on anyone continuing to do business with them if a ceasefire does not take effect in, I believe, it's 40 days?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, I think it's a little over that. But yeah, this is probably the most difficult type of tariff or sanction to put on, because it's extraterritoriality. So we're prohibiting countries from doing business with Russia, which is something that really creates resentment and a great deal of backlash. Countries usually find a way of going around these sanctions.  often will say, I'm not going to abide to that. India. So, it's a tough type of sanction to do. It's not something the president has done a lot of, just Venezuela and oil. So, we will have to see. It's a long way away. But a cease-fire is a big hurdle.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So, you know, it's a big move. So what signal should investors take from that, just the general idea that the president's determined to do something here, or that the president is making motions toward doing something, but it's something that's not actually probably going to happen?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I would say, in this instance with Russia, it is an example of the president using tariffs, using sanctions as a negotiating tool. I don't think the president wants to put sanctions on Russia. If he did, he would have done so yesterday.  uh... but so in a hundred percent you know that this this is a a negotiation level so i believe yes i believe this is a tactic i believe he wants to find a way of reaching a deal with russia uh... but i i don't think this is going to be something permanent why do you think they haven't been more trade deals yet  Well, it's tough. It's — on one hand, they take a long time. A typical trade deal would take 12 to 18 months with one country. We're trying to do deals with 12 countries. I do believe that what the president is looking for are term sheets, frameworks, conceptual deals, where we have a deal to continue to negotiate, and then the specter of tariffs is leaning over that negotiation.  I think that is what will get us across August 1. I hope we'll see quite a few deals. I don't think we'll see all of them. So it is a possibility that some countries will receive tariffs as of August 1.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How much do you think the performance of the U.S. economy through a year end will factor into what kinds of deals actually end up getting done?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, I think that's a good question. You know, up until now, the president has walked a tightrope, and he's been able to use tariffs, threaten with tariffs, and the U.S. economy has held still. We'll see tomorrow what happens if inflation is up. So that will be something that is a consistent signal  that the president will look at, although I don't think he will back away totally from tariffs. But, yes, as time goes by and these tariffs begin to show up in the economy, I'm sure that will temper him. Doesn't mean he'll walk away from them, but I'm sure it will.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And it seems the Fed  And the markets play into that, as well, as different as they are from the economy in general. The Fed's intentions when it comes to interest rates affect not only the markets, but eventually people's freedom to spend, certainly, where credit is concerned. Should we expect, as well, as the economy shifts toward the end of the year, that the president will have that in mind as he considers these tariff negotiations?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Sure. You know, what's been happening is, on one hand, exporters are paying a little bit more than we expected. Exporters are eating part of the tariff. And then there's a lot of forward buying going. You take copper, for example, which at this point is just a threat. Importers have forward bought four or five months. At least they've ordered four or five months. So that's keeping inflation in the pipeline away from the market. I think that's happening across industries.  With time, we will see that inching up. Time is the president's enemy here. It is the level of tariff, but, importantly, it's how long they last. And the more time goes on, the worse it is. So, this is the tightrope the president's walking. I believe he wants some good frameworks before August 1, although I don't think there will be frameworks with everyone. I believe the European Union is probably the toughest. So, we may see some tariffs go on the European Union.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer asks about the effectiveness of tariffs, the potential signals to investors, and the influence of the US economy and Fed on tariff negotiations.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Carlos Gutierrez views the 100% tariff threat on Russia as a negotiating tactic, unlikely to be implemented permanently. He notes the challenges in enforcing extraterritorial sanctions and suggests that the President aims for term sheets and frameworks rather than comprehensive trade deals by August 1st. Gutierrez also emphasises the economic impact of tariffs, including forward buying, inflation, and the tightrope the President is walking to avoid economic backlash.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the use of tariffs as a negotiating tool by the US President, focusing on the threats to Russia, the EU, and Mexico, and their potential impact on the US economy and trade deals.

video_title: Don't yet know if IPO market is back to full health, says Raymond James' Sunaina Sinha Haldea

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: of an IPO market returning to health. Will the enthusiasm continue? Joining me now on set is Sunaina Sinha-Haldea.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I think the window's open. We can feel the breeze. But is it fully open in that we can understand that this to be a sustained period of issuances? We do not know yet. I think having these debuts go well with Circle and CoreWeave certainly helps. The other thing that has been a great marker has been over 100 IPOs, 80% higher issuance in the first half of 2025 than the same time last year.  great signal for the markets. But we require policy stability. When you look at the IPO pipeline, it's not as full as the market would like. A lot of folks are in watch and wait mode, especially with regards to their trophy assets that are often held in private equity funds. They want to make sure that there's a clearly established window that opens before they launch.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: That's what I'm remembering, is that the risk assets suffered especially in early April when the president rolled out those initial  the

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And now we have another gating item in August as to whether he follows through, whether there's another retrade here. So investors are in let's-watch-and-wait mode. Let's wait for policy stability on two fronts. What path is the Fed taking? And what path are these tariffs happening in terms of their implications on the economy? We'll see with the inflation prints tomorrow whether we see any pass-through coming good at all.  So, when there is a good line of sight that there's stability across the two, that's when you'll see the window really crack open fully and all the issuances that are waiting in the wings to come out. Right now, there'll be folks testing the market, as we've seen, but not quite in a sustained way.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Let me ask you about private markets in general. It's been a hot topic for a couple years now. We've talked to you about it. There's also this sense out there now that the excitement around private markets is changing the nature of how even decisions are investments are being made. And that might kill the goose that laid the golden egg. How do you see it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I think what's important is that because we've had really subdued capital markets on the public side over the last couple of years when it comes to exits and liquidity via IPOs, you've seen behavior patterns change in the private markets. What does that mean? Private equity runs on a clock. Four or five years to buy assets, four or five years thereafter to sell assets. We've had a very bearish cycle over the last three years when it comes to selling things.  seen M&A volumes down. We'll see if they pick up. We're starting to see all the green shoots in that direction. But we still need that full comeback after the 2021 period. We've started to see the IPO window open. We just talked about that. But we still don't have a fully clear path to selling some of the assets that were bought in that 2019 to 2022 vintage periods in private markets. That's what I think you're alluding to, John.  What happens to those assets that are now five, six, seven years old, sitting in private markets? They have to be sold. So the question is, how?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: What do investors need to be careful of? Retail investors who are being pitched these private market assets for the first time, and my sense is they're being pitched it based on this long history of how these assets, these types of assets have performed, but we're in a period now where those assets aren't necessarily performing in the way that they used to.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Now, private markets is a very large asset class. Retail investors need to know what they're buying. There are certainly private assets that have shorter durations and more history of distribution. So private credit is an example. Secondaries market, another very good example, where the J curve, where the time between investing your first dollar and getting the same dollar out  is much, much shorter and not as deep a period of time to wait. So all of those strategies help. In fact, those are the strategies I've seen the most traction from retail investors over the last year and a half or so. Now, the other thing for them to watch is making sure that the liquidity profile matches the assets they're buying. If they're buying long dated funds in an interval fund structure, then they've got to know that there isn't much liquidity there in the short term. However, if they're buying shorter term instruments, maybe they can be more tolerant of that.

summary.unstructured_summary:
{'high_level_summary': 'The conversation discusses the health of the IPO market and its potential for sustained growth. It also touches on the state of private markets and the risks and considerations for investors, particularly retail investors, in both markets.', 'SPEAKER_00': 'The host asks about the IPO market\'s enthusiasm, its potential for sustainability, and the impact of policy stability on IPO issuances. He also shifts the focus to private markets, exploring how changing behaviour patterns and excitement might affect decision-making. Additionally, he questions the risks for retail investors in private market assets.', 'SPEAKER_01': 'Sunaina Sinha-Haldea analyses the IPO market, noting that while the window is open due to successful debuts and increased issuance, policy stability is crucial for a sustained period. She highlights two key policy fronts
: the Fed\'s path and tariff implications. Sinha-Haldea also discusses the private markets, explaining how subdued public capital markets have changed behaviour patterns. video_title: Bitcoin hits new record above $123,000 as 'Crypto Week' kicks off on Capitol Hill: CNBC Crypto World

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Today, Bitcoin notches yet another new all-time high, this time above $123,000. CryptoWeek kicks off on Capitol Hill, where the House will debate a series of crypto-related bills. And Pantera's Cosmo Xiong discusses the growing trend of corporate crypto treasuries.  Welcome to CBC's Crypto World, I'm Brandon Gomez. Bitcoin hit another new record to kick off the week. As of noon Eastern, Bitcoin traded close to $120,000, but briefly crossed $123,000 this morning, notching a new record. Ether climbed more than 0.5% to $3,000, and XRP rose nearly 4%.  The fresh high for Bitcoin comes amid strong ETF inflows and moves by U.S. lawmakers aimed at clearer regulation for the industry. Professional capital management founder and CEO Anthony Pompliano joined CNBC's Squawk Box to discuss some of the factors that helped Bitcoin jump to new records.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I think that Wall Street's full undivided attention now is on Bitcoin. And really, there's three things that drove this move. The first is that there's been record inflows into the ETFs. So last Thursday, $1.2 billion, second highest day. Those ETFs now collectively have over $140 billion. BlackRock's fund is now almost $90 billion in about a year. They went from not having a Bitcoin ETF to now they have a top 20 largest ETF in the world.  So there's a lot of inflows there. Second thing is the options expired at the end of Q2. And so all that downward pressure on Bitcoin obviously goes away. That helps. Kind of like a beach ball getting put underneath the water. Right. Obviously can pop back up. And then the third thing is that there was a lot of short sellers and you started to see that build up. And as they got blown out as Bitcoin ran.  You get into this price discovery phase. If you go back to November, we went from $70,000 to $90,000 in about two to three weeks. And $70,000 was a new all-time high. What we're watching now is we broke through that $110,000 range. That was the previous all-time high. I don't know if it goes to $140,000, but it sure is going to make a big move here because you are in a true price discovery phase.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay, let's talk about the top stories. Crypto Week on Capitol Hill kicks off today. The House of Representatives picked the week's nickname as the lower chamber prepares to debate three major crypto bills. The Clarity Act, aimed at establishing a clear regulatory framework for crypto. The Genius Act, stable coin regulation bill, which the Senate passed last month. And the Anti-CBDC Surveillance State Act, proposed legislation aimed at preventing the Fed from issuing a retail central bank digital currency.  The goal of that bill? To limit potential government surveillance capabilities. Meantime, some House Democrats have chosen their own nickname for this week, Anti-Crypto Corruption Week. Democrats on the House Financial Services Committee pointed to President Trump's quote, meme coin scam. Ranking member Maxine Waters and other committee Democrats are calling on lawmakers to vote no on the Clarity and Genius Acts, which they claim give the president the green light to continue crypto dealings in his name.  Next, Jeremy Allaire, co-founder and CEO of stablecoin issuer Circle, joined CNBC's Money Movers this morning to discuss progress for stablecoin legislation in the U.S. and his company's success since going public last month.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's been an exciting time, obviously, for what we do. I think  just overall the awareness about stable coins the role that they can play major institutions really making it clear that this is going to be a key part of the way money moves in the world. And you know as the leading regulated stable coin network in the world we're I think in a really you know we're in a great place to to build on that. And you know this is a moment where  It's been a long time since you've actually had an upgrade to the financial system to the very nature of what electronic money is. And digital currency really represents that. And you know we're as I like to say still in the very early days of this. And so we think about just like Treasury Secretary Besson talks about trillions of dollars of stable coins in the coming years.  major investment banks and others looking at trillions of dollars to stable coins. We can imagine a world where stable coin money is the primary way that transactions happen on the Internet. And that's that's what we're going after.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Shares of Circle have rocketed more than 530 percent since its initial public offering on June 5th.  as investors prepare for the potential of stablecoin regulation in the U.S. Back to Trump's meme coin as we round out the top stories, crypto billionaire Justin Sun is buying another $100 million worth of that meme coin, doubling his total known stake of digital coins tied to the president. The founder of the Tron blockchain made the announcement on X last week, adding that the Trump-linked digital coins will soon be tradable on Tron.  Sun, who has rapidly emerged as one of the Trump crypto ecosystem's biggest whales, is currently working to resolve a civil fraud case with the SEC. Back in 2023, the agency charged Sun and his companies for alleged fraud and other securities law violations.  All right, turning to crypto treasuries for our main story. Earlier this month, Pantera Capital, an investment firm focused on crypto and blockchain technology, launched a new fund focused on digital asset treasury-related investments. CryptoWorld's Tanaya McKeel spoke with Pantera's Cosmos Xiong about crypto treasury reserve strategies in general.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Cosmo, thank you so much for joining me on Crypto World today. Let's talk Bitmine. They made a splash last week when they said that they're going to continue their Bitcoin mining operations, but they're going to pivot to make ETH their primary focus for their primary asset for their treasury. Pantera did back this deal. They also backed, I believe, 21 and DeFi Development Core. Talk about Bitmine. Why?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, look, thank you for having me. It's a really exciting time to be talking about these companies. I think there's a couple of points to make here, which is that we are seeing the emergence of a new category of companies. And it's really rare to find oneself at the onset of that. And so we're pretty fortunate to have really leaned in early as investors in this space of digital asset treasuries, and now getting the recognition for some of these investments in the public markets.  As we think about, you know, why we wanted to participate in these in particular, you know, we really like, as investors in blockchain assets for some time, we are big proponents of the large blockchains like Bitcoin, like Ethereum and like Solana. And it's always made sense to us that there could be, if MicroStrategy can succeed in having that playbook in Bitcoin, there can be others as well. And we want to back the best teams that are doing that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How many companies would you say you've spoken with in the last couple of months that are pursuing this type of treasury strategy operation? What is it that you're looking for and what are the types of things you're filtering out?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, look, when we started investing this back in April, at the time, it was definitely not a foregone conclusion that any of this would work, right? We'd seen micro strategy work for a few years in the U.S. and then we saw MetaPlanet be a great success in Japan. And there are a few others across the world, but none that really took off in a very big way.  And so when we were first approached by a Solana team that was looking to do something like MicroStrategy was doing, but except a Bitcoin, they're doing it with Solana. I thought that was very interesting. As a firm, we've been very excited and bullish on Solana's prospects as a large generalized contract blockchain that others will use. And so Solana has actually been the second largest position at Pantera for a long time, just behind Bitcoin. And so when someone came to us saying, we're going to tap the US capital markets, the  the, the, the, the excitement, the creativity, the financial engineering that exists in the U S in tandem with pairing that with Solana, a token that we are very excited about on an underlying basis. We thought, look, this is a really interesting time to try to lean in and see if the experiment works. This experiment of creating additional treasury, digital asset treasury beyond just micro strategy. And it worked to our, you know, to our pleasant surprise based on our underwriting, our underwriting played out. And then that's why we also leaned in with, with Cantor equity partners when  Cantor approached us about having the Tether and SoftBank collective come together to create a competitive micro strategy. I just thought, wow, that makes a lot of sense, just as much sense as the Solano loan that we just backed. And so we really helped anchor that deal as an outside investor. And then from there, it just became this explosion, this almost big bang like event where all of a sudden everyone saw the success of DeFi DevCorp.  of canter equity partners, or 21 as it will be renamed. And really a lot of teams started coming to market. And so it's become a much larger and more, more boolean trend than perhaps I might've thought when we first started. In the last three months, I've now taken 70 to 80 pitches of teams trying to do this. Now, naturally, when you see something like that, it's very normal or very reasonable to say that, you know, excess returns invites competition, competition drives down returns. And so eventually,  there will be some successes that I think are really big outcomes, but there will also be plenty of failures, just like there is with any startup universe, as there is always creative destruction. And so of those 70 pitches, we've done now six investments in the space that we're all pretty excited about, and we're continuing to think about and evaluate more.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How far down the spectrum of crypto assets do you see this going? Do you see it moving to an XRP or a Dogecoin? When I talk to a lot of institutional type investors, they say we're not really interested in any cryptocurrencies beyond the first three, Bitcoin, ETH, Solana. So how far do you see this going?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, it's a great question. And something that we see a lot, especially because I do think in the future, they're just like with any industry, there's it's not, it's not a pure monopoly. And so I do think there will be two or three Bitcoin based digital asset treasury companies, there'll be two or three ETH DATs, there'll be two or three Solana DATs. And  And I think that's probably how it all shakes out today. There's a lot more than that. And I expect there to be many more that launched and maybe not the leaders today. We'll be the leaders of tomorrow. We'll see how that plays out. As we go down the token spectrum though, as I think about what really works or why these work, you really have to have a traditional investor buy-in, right? Institutional investor buy-in to get to scale.  I think there are a lot of teams that are playing for different outcomes. Some teams are playing for that micro strategy like outcome. There are some teams that are playing for a smaller outcome. I think for smaller outcomes, it doesn't matter as much, but like that's less interesting to us. For the bigger outcomes, you really need to hit certain thresholds of market cap before institutional investors take you seriously.  in order to really tap the convertible debt market, you probably need a billion dollar public float company. And when you think about that, there's really only so many tokens that can support a billion dollar digital asset treasury company. If the token itself doesn't have a large market cap, it's not going to support it. And so when I think about that, it probably means you're looking at the top 10, 15 tokens that really have enough practical market cap to support something like this. And then from a  From an acceptance perspective, a big part of the thesis here is that you have to have strong belief by a lot of people in the long-term trajectory of this token, not just from crypto natives, but from broader traditional investors. And there are only so many tokens that have that really broad appeal. Clearly, Bitcoin, Solana, and ETH do. There are certainly a few others that have very, very broad appeal, whether it's stuff like Ripple or Cardano or Doge that have just been around for so long that people know about them.  that I think those have a shot at really making it. Obviously less of a shot because they have less of a real, many people don't believe that as much as of a real long-term trajectory, but there's definitely possibility that because they have so much broad awareness that it could work.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Okay, that's all for Crypto World today. We're back again tomorrow and we'll see you then.
