video_title: Stacey Abrams on her new book and the ethical questions of AI

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Elon Musk's artificial intelligence chatbot, Grok, issued an apology over the weekend after it made numerous anti-Semitic social media posts. And some of those comments, they went as far as praising Hitler. All of this raising questions about a need for more regulation of new tech. Joining me now, someone who is asking those very questions in her new thriller novel, Coded Justice, hitting shelves tomorrow. Former Georgia House Minority Leader Stacey Abrams. Stacey, thank you for joining us. Thanks for having me.  You cover so much in your books. I mean, from your Selina Montgomery days, now to Avery Keene. What inspired Avery Keene and what made you want to take on this topic in particular?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Avery Keene was born out of a story I wanted to tell almost a decade ago.  about the Supreme Court and what it feels like to have responsibility but no power. And so that was the very first Avery Keene novel, While Justice Sleeps. She came back having created a lot of havoc and showed up in Rogue Justice to address the question of what do you do when the system fails you and who's responsible? And this one is about what happens when the right intentions turn dastardly.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: When you say responsibility but no power, explain that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I wanted Avery to begin her story and her journey as a law clerk, meaning that she was thrust into this situation where she actually had the life of a Supreme Court justice in her hand. But she could not have, she didn't have the authority, but she didn't have the power to make big decisions. She had to navigate within a system that wasn't designed for her.  And I wanted her to choose to do something, as opposed to a lot of our hero stories where you just, you have no choice but to act. She had a choice, and I wanted her to make the affirmative decision to lean in, because too often we feel like we can't do something unless we have to, and often it's because we have responsibility, but we don't think we have the power to make things right. And sometimes not having the power is just not an excuse.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So stepping into the real world, what does that affirmative choice look like when it comes to the regulation of things like AI and what we saw happen just over the weekend?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Exactly. So Avery Keene in this book is brought on as an internal investigator. She's left the Supreme Court behind, and she's now working for a tech firm.  That tech firm is trying to do the right thing with AI. They're trying to address the biases. I mean what we saw happen over the weekend was about having a language model that was trained on epithets and hatred and venom. And that's what happens when when the technology learns the wrong thing it produces the wrong thing. So she's brought in because the company wants to do the right thing.  The problem is you can't undo centuries of bad action with good intention. And sometimes even our best intentions run into our ambitions. And so she's got to help navigate that for her client who may or may not be the good guy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And they run into the structures that sometimes, as you mentioned, aren't built for our inclusion. You said this to some of our friends this weekend on MSNBC, and I was fascinated. You said, quote, if you can control data, you can control dissent. If you can control the algorithm, you can decide who gets privilege and who doesn't. You can target communities you don't like.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And that's exactly what we are watching happen. When there was a narrative during the mega bill debate about whether AI should be regulated or not, that wasn't coming out of thin air. It was states that are looking at the issues that Joy Boulamwini looks at in unmasking AI, where discrimination can be built into the system, where, yes, it's great if you can walk up to your building and it can scan your face, but what if it runs that through a database and falsely matches you to a criminal?  You now have entire communities that are at risk because we haven't trained the data to do the right thing. And it needs to be upgraded. It needs to be upgraded. But we also have to ask hard questions. Who's in charge? What decisions are they making? And who are they thinking about when they make those decisions?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We thank you for watching. And remember, stay updated on breaking news and top stories on the NBC News app or watch live on our YouTube channel.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Stacey Abrams, the author, explains that her protagonist Avery Keene navigates situations where she has responsibility but no power. In "Coded Justice", Avery works for a tech firm trying to address AI biases. Abrams emphasises that good intentions alone cannot undo systemic issues, highlighting the risks of AI discrimination and the need for robust regulation and oversight to ensure fairness and accountability.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host introduces the topic of AI regulation through Elon Musk's chatbot Grok's anti-Semitic posts. They ask Stacey Abrams about her thriller novel "Coded Justice" and its connection to real-world AI issues, seeking her insights on the consequences of unregulated AI and the role of intention versus ambition in tech development.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the need for AI regulation, drawing parallels between the fictional protagonist Avery Keene's challenges and real-world issues. It highlights how AI can perpetuate biases and the dangers of unchecked technology, emphasising the importance of responsible development and oversight.

video_title: Trump has 'figured out that Putin is the problem,' says fmr. US Ambassador to Ukraine

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Let me turn to Andrea. Andrea, so good to have you here with us. You know that President Trump had falsely accused Ukraine of starting this war at earlier times. Today, talking about their bravery, which he has acknowledged before, but there was a notable difference, it seemed.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: This was so different from that really operatic  experience that we all saw the drama in the Oval Office with President Zelensky where he was shown the door without even being given the lunch that was scheduled with the president and certainly not getting the mineral deal that had been arranged by the Treasury Secretary without any kind of signature and basically told you know the blow-up really happened when the vice president seized on the fact that Zelensky  appropriately by the rest of the world's view, said that Ukraine hadn't started the war and pushed back against that, and they seized on that in what looked like a setup, frankly, an ambush. Well, that has certainly changed. And to what caused this change, I think you saw the beginnings of it yourself.  When you were at NATO, and you were in that news conference, and a young woman stood up and talked about the Russian attempt. Oh, her husband.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yes. Her husband serving.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And she said, where are you from? And the president said, where are you from? Ukraine. And is your husband serving? And yes. And since that time, we've seen a notable difference in impatience, a frustration by the president. He's expressed it using a term, a BS term.  And notably, today he signaled for the first time that he had indicated at some point that Putin was going to go along with ending the war. And Melania, he'd never mentioned her in the context.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That was interesting, yes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Melania, the first lady, said, oh yes, but they bombed a nursing home.  And as Courtney has just been reporting, there were 700 drone strikes on one night. Kiev was being hammered. The battering of Ukraine in the last week or so since the president's phone call with Vladimir Putin, the first phone call, the first of two, has been, you know, just horrendous, the most since the war began.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And the president has also kind of picked up the tempo of talking to Zelensky. And we just, colleagues here just handed me a note that he, Zelensky, has posted on X, that he spoke with the president, called it a good conversation, and he expressed that they would talk more frequently, share details about his meeting with the secretary general. Again, clearly Zelensky is  very

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Absolutely. And Zelensky has been coached by Keir Starmer, the British Prime Minister, after that disastrous Oval Office experience, on how to, quote, handle Donald Trump. The first overture was at the Vatican when they were there for the funeral services for the Pope. That seemed like a turning point. That seemed like that knee-to-knee, chair-to-chair meeting in the Vatican.  There have been a couple of other overtures, and then on July 4th there was a key conversation. The Financial Times has reported, and I've gotten some independent confirmation from diplomatic sources, that that conversation included the President of the United States demanding that there be some changes  in the Ukrainian cabinet and top leadership, including the changeover of the Ukrainian ambassador.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Now, she is one of the most prominent people that Americans know, who is a Ukrainian official serving here in the United States. Oksana has been so prominent and a very passionate advocate for her country. What do you see as happening with this, if she is out of that position? Is this a normal thing?  rotation or something else?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: There is a normal rotation involved but she has been the face of the Ukrainian rallying of support. I've been at so many occasions with her. At one point she was at a State of the Union meeting and she's at the Kennedy Center at events. She gets standing ovations at  numerous events around the country. She's traveled throughout the country. She has been a prominent advocate. She also would be critical in the reconstruction. She's a former finance minister in the cabinet.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That's something people probably don't know.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And she's very, very experienced. And I think it will be a loss.  But the backstory here is that even though she had gone to an event in Utah on a Republican congressional campaign event, she went to one in Scranton, Pennsylvania. And Pennsylvania, as you know, is a real touch. And that was about munitions being built in Pennsylvania. Exactly.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It was a factory visit.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It was not political. Yes. But that set off the MAGA universe and the White House. And they have been campaigning against her ever since.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, someone who knows what it's like to be in the ambassador ranks is Bill Taylor, who served as the United States ambassador to Ukraine. Again, our audience has seen you in your many high-profile appearances before Congress and commenting on all of this. What do you make of how the president has shifted his toolkit today?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Kelly, I think it's great that the president has figured out that Putin's the problem.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Long time coming.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Long time coming. But he's clearly made that determination. He clearly understands that Putin has been the problem. You know, the president has tried to work on this. He's, as you've reported, you know, in the campaign, he was talking about 24 hours. But he's put a lot of time and effort into this. And now he's finally figured out that Putin is the problem. Putin is the obstacle to a very high priority. And he's taking  Trump is now taking some action to put some pressure on Putin.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I was struck today, too, by his reference. Although he didn't directly call him an assassin, he referenced him as an assassin. And that seemed like much harsher language than we have typically seen. At times, I've been in the room with President Trump and President Putin where he took his word over the US intelligence. So to use that kind of language, do you sense that this is a frustration that has just hit a boiling point?  And do you, from your vast experience with Putin and this landscape, is he likely to change his tactics?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Putin is unlikely to change his tactics until he gets pressure. And President Trump has started that today. With the economic pressure, these tariffs we've been talking about, with the weapons. And it's not just those two specific things, it's also the indication that we're going to be there for, we're going to support the Ukrainians for the longer term.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So there was a 50-day component to this, where the president says Putin has 50 days to reach a peace deal before these secondary tariffs would go into effect. When you consider what that means in the real-world calendar of the summertime and the military advantages of that time period, is that too much time?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I think it's too much time. However, the Indians and the Chinese have to worry that 100% tariffs on all of their goods, which is not out of the question since we've seen President Trump do that level of tariffs before. It gives them time, actually, to reduce their sale, their purchases of Russian oil. And that's the goal. The goal is to reduce the flow of resources, money, funds, into the Russian economy that is supporting this war.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And what are you watching in terms of what's happening on the ground politically inside Ukraine with some of the pressures about the anti-corruption movement, some of the other voices that are not in Zelensky's camp? Anything stand out to you there?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Kelly, what stands out to me is the opposition  leaders, as well as the broad society, support the president. In the time of war, they're supporting him. They're not talking about elections. They're not talking about being concerned about decisions. They are supporting the president. They are united against the Russians, let's be clear. But that shows up as support for the president.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Let's dip into a piece of what the president had to say today in this consequential meeting with the NATO Secretary General, Mark Rutte.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I speak to him a lot about getting this thing done. And I always hang up and say, well, that was a nice phone call. And then missiles launched into Kiev and some other city. I don't want to say he's an assassin, but he's a tough guy. It's been proven over the years. He's fooled a lot of people. He fooled Bush. He fooled a lot of people. He fooled Clinton, Bush, Obama, Biden. He didn't fool me.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: He didn't fool me. That's an interesting assessment, when clearly the president had publicly said that he thought he would have real influence over Putin over the last six months, and that has not come to pass.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Putin has been fooling President Trump for six months. You're absolutely right. Putin has been, the president has said, tapping him along. The president has now realized that that's what's going on. And he's turned around. He's now going to, he's not going to take that any longer. He's going to put pressure on Putin.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And were you struck by the president talking about the importance of a strong Europe? Because clearly they're in the neighborhood. He has often said the U.S. is protected by an ocean. Do you see that as more support for allies there?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Absolutely. Absolutely. That's another change. President Trump, strong support for the Europeans, strong support for NATO.  at the NATO summit last month. Strong support for Article 5, the attack on one's attack on all. That is an indication that their support, that NATO is united. The United States, being a member, the main member, lead member, united with the rest of NATO. That's a strong support. And as you just reported, I think Courtney just reported, the NATO infrastructure is going to start coordinating this assistance going into Ukraine.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We often watch when the president changes in tone a little. It'll be interesting to see if this is an enduring shift on Putin and elsewhere. Thank you, Ambassador. Appreciate your time today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We thank you for watching. And remember, stay updated on breaking news and top stories on the NBC News app or watch live on our YouTube channel.

lines.text: Well, first of all, Heather, I guess, unlike you, I actually want to protect law enforcement officers who serve and sacrifice, put their life on the line to keep us safe. Appreciate your question.

summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses immigration enforcement, ICE, and the role of law enforcement. SPEAKER_01 defends ICE and highlights the dangers faced by officers, while SPEAKER_00 accuses ICE of kidnapping and disappearing people. SPEAKER_01 also brings up the Epstein files and shifts the focus to crimes committed by illegal immigrants.

video_title: BREAKING NEWS: Gov. Greg Abbott Provides Update On Texas Flooding Response And Recovery Efforts

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: with us here today and especially want to thank those who were just involved in briefing me on giving me this area, this region are dealing with as well as all the first responders in the room behind me and what they've been doing to prioritize saving lives.  Obviously, there are enormous concerns and challenges that we're dealing with still in the Kerrville area. At the same time that we're responding to Kerrville, there have been an abundance of storms and large swaths of the state of Texas that have impacted lives and taken lives and destroyed homes, facilities, buildings, and roads across large regions in central Texas.  As a reminder, I have declared 21 counties in my Governor Disaster Declaration. They include Bandera, Bear, Burnett, Colwell, Koch, Camaro, Concho, Gillespie, Guadalupe, Kendall, Kerr, Kimball, Leno, Mason, McCullough, Menard, Reeves, Sanseva, Tom Green, Travis, and  the role that the state of Texas is going to play in each of those counties that are going through these enormous challenges. On top of that I have to tell you new news and that is

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: There are additional communities that need to be aware.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: They're going to be facing challenges of their own. They include areas surrounding the communities of Uvalde, Del Rio, and Konkan. The state is already deploying resources in those regions to help them get prepared. We'll be working with local officials in those regions just as we have in these other regions.  and in those regions as well as in Travis and Williamson County as well as in Kerr County. Job number one is always saving lives, protecting lives and finding those who have lost their lives and that is a 24-7 operation that we are unrelenting in continuing to pursue. That includes especially if you look at  The areas in either in Williamson or Travis County or counties nearby, if you saw the rushing waters over the past 24 hours, you know that there were an extraordinary number of people who had to be rescued. Dozens of people were rescued because of our extraordinary first responder teams. And I want to thank the Gab Mortons who have really stepped up and done a great job, National Guard, Texas Department of Public Safety, local firefighters and local first responders, as well as Texas Task Force One and Texas Task Force Two.  and others who are truly saving lives. Many Texans' lives have been endangered. Most of those lives have been rescued by our first responders here in the state of Texas.  The latest numbers of what we see both in the state, and I'll talk about the local counties where we are, as it concerns Texans who were lost, as well as those who are missing. Statewide, there's a total of 131 fatalities to be reported. Breaking that down in current and nearby counties. In Travis County, nine people have lost their lives, there were three missing.  And Burnett County, four who lost their lives, and there's one missing. In Williamson County, there were three who lost their lives, and no one is missing at this time.  The stories about those who've been swept away is gut-wrenching and heartbreaking. And the kind of thing that spurs us to do even more to make sure that we're going to be searching and finding everybody that we can, as well as spurring the response that both the state and local governments, as well as the federal government, will have to make sure that we fully address the challenges that Texans have faced over the past week or so.  In addition to the lives of our fellow Texans, there are homes that have been destroyed, people who don't have a place to stay. The state is working with local officials to address those needs. There's also infrastructure around those people that make living where they are or accessing their home either difficult or impossible. I visited one today. I visited the Big Sandy Creek Bridge.  and was astonished at what I saw. If you haven't seen it, it's a two-lane road and has two yellow lines in the middle of it to divide one roadway from the other from going in opposite directions. And the center part of the bridge was literally moved about half a foot in one direction, which shows the power of the water that was pushing through there.  Let me just add this. All of America has their eyes on what's going on in Texas. And Americans are praying, caring for, and helping our state so much. It's just unbelievable.  But quite literally, half of the states of the United States are providing resources to help Texans either deal with those who are missing, help rebuild, whatever the need is. And I want to root out the states, the 25 states, that are assisting Texas right now.  Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Maine, Michigan, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, and Wisconsin. You can see one thing that's quite obvious. And that is, it doesn't matter if they're a red state or a blue state.  They are fellow Americans. And when times get tough, Americans come together. That is even more true as it concerns Texans. This has been an extraordinarily challenging time, if not the most extraordinarily challenging time that Texans have faced. And in typical Texas fashion, Texans have united, come together. And as I was visiting the Big Sandy Creek Bridge area, there was a young man who lived in what had been a marooned area.  And he said, you know, at times like this, we are community. And everybody comes together and supports each other. And that's exactly what I see across the entire state. I'm proud of our fellow Texans, proud of our fellow Americans, for the way they've all leaned into this to ensure that we as a state, we as a people, are going to be able to respond to this and deal with this as rapidly as possible. Now I'm going to turn things over to Director Williams with the Texas Department of Transportation.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thank you, Governor. As you mentioned, our efforts here in the Central Texas area now are primarily focused on the rebuilding of the bridge at Cow Creek at RM 1431. Throughout this event, for the past couple of, for the past few weeks, we've been supporting the efforts to repair and replace roads that have been damaged in Williamson and Travis County, Burnett Counties.  The one remaining section that we're focused on is the bridge at Cow Creek. On the Monday after the bridge washed out, the bridge washed out on a Saturday morning, we had contractors in place with heavy equipment that were beginning the work of removing the debris from that bridge that was completely destroyed.  And so that process is continuing as we speak. In addition, our bridge teams with the Austin District of the Texas Department of Transportation have been working literally 24-7 to design a new bridge to replace that bridge that was washed out. We've also been working with members of the Federal Highway Administration that were on site with us this past Monday as well to review that damage.  We've released those bids to contractors now that we have a complete design in hand. We expect to have bids back from those contractors on Wednesday of this week. And then after we award that contract, we will begin the process of transitioning from the debris removal contract that is still out there with a lot of heavy equipment today  to the construction work on the new bridge. We're targeting a 60-day construction period for that bridge with some significant incentives to work to reduce the time frame for the replacement of that bridge by at least 20 days if we can. And so we know that that's a very significantly  important bridge. It's an important travel corridor between Marble Falls, Lago Vista, and Cedar Park. A lot of people commute back and forth. The school year will be coming up soon. We have some students that attend Marble Falls ISD that live on the east side of that bridge, and so we need to be able to have plans in place to accommodate them. We're working with the school district on that as well. Overall, though, we've made some significant progress statewide. We're continuing, Governor, as you know, to work  in the Kerrville Hunt area on State Highway 39 and Ranch Road 1340 to repair and replace the bridges and the roads that were damaged there. We did, as you also spoke about, experience some flooding and some additional damage just in the past couple of days.  And we had road impacts. We had 49 roads that were impacted over the past 24 hours. 37 of those were closed due to high water, and some of those were damaged. But we're going to be able to get those turned around and replaced and repaired relatively quickly. And hopefully, the water will go down, and we'll get a break from the rain. So thank you for the briefing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Thank you very much. Now, Lieutenant Colonel Baker.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you, Governor. Ben Baker, Lieutenant Colonel, Texas Game Wardens. Before I get into a search and recovery efforts and Texas Game Wardens' response to this historic tragedy of a series of events in central Texas and in Carr County, I'd like to just remind everybody that all of these efforts and all through this tragedy, Texas comes together under Governor Abbott's strong leadership  of the Texas Department of Emergency Management, Department of Public Safety, all of our local first responders, all of our local EMS, all of our local volunteers, and everybody who is in Texas who comes together in such a tragic time and unites to help the people of Texas. Texas Game Wardens, as of July 3rd, through the State Operations Center, were set up and poised in anticipation of a flooding event.  Through the calls coming in late and early of July 4th, Texas game wardens were deployed to Kerr County. Since then, around 300 game wardens have deployed in the Kerr County and surrounding areas. In anticipation of other flooding occurring in Central Texas, we were able to strategically stage, through the Texas Division of Emergency Management, several swift water assets in Central Texas out of the Kerr County area, just in case this flooding grew a little more widespread.  Unfortunately, it did grow a little more widespread and we started conducting rescue operations not only through our swift water technicians, but our aviation, multiple canine searches and through our drone team.  Through those, we were able to successfully rescue several individuals and multiple evacuations. We currently have, through Texas Task Force 1, wardens embedded in multiple search groups, searching Cal and Sandy Creek, looking for the remaining victims of this terrible tragedy. We've also got our canine detection teams in  in deployment with the search and rescue teams and our aviation still embedded in these. We remain dedicated to Texas, we remain dedicated to the people of the state of Texas, and Texas Game Wardens remain dedicated and ready on standby, Governor.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Helping to do a great job to see the videos of you all out in the middle of conducting rescues and literally saving our fellow Texans has been nothing short of miraculous. So thank you and all the game wardens for what you've been doing. Now the Travis County ESD Assistant Chief Weidman. Thank you, Governor. Let me get a little bit closer right there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Just after midnight, we started receiving the calls. And within several hours, we had logged 50 rescues, saving hundreds of Texans through our area. And this was noted and supported by our mutual aid and automatic aid partners throughout Travis County.  Within 12 hours of the incident starting, the governor's office as well as TDEM had sent us many resources. We supported our operations and was able to have us start setting up command structure a little bit more enhanced to start helping others.  And what we would like to point out is, as ESD, we recognize the recovery will not happen overnight. It'll be a long and difficult road, but we're committed to staying engaged, showing up, and working hard alongside those we serve. This is our home, too. We're members of this community, and we're committed to helping each one of our neighbors.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Thank you. And now, Chief Nemcat.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thank you, Governor. And listen, I want to thank you all in the press for helping us get this message out. Life safety remains our number one priority. As such, as we've talked about additional rains coming into the state, we have pre-positioned swift water rescue assets, as the governor mentioned, around Uvalde, around El Rio, and around Concan. Help us get that message down to those folks to turn around, don't drown, don't drive through a low water crossing if you can't see the road in front of you.  And if you were in a low-lying area, please plan on moving to higher ground once the rain starts to come. Another thing I need you to remember is it does not have to be raining where you are in order for you to be impacted by flooding. Second, the governor mentioned the 21 counties in his declaration. We have six counties right now that are in the federal declaration for individual assistance. Those counties are Burnet,  Kerr, San Saba, Tom Green, Travis, and Williamson for individual assistance. We have a disaster recovery center open in Kerr County right now, and you will be hearing from your local partners here, many of those standing behind us, about the disaster recovery centers that will be opening in Travis and Williamson counties very soon.  On the public assistance side, this is the money that goes to the local governments to help with emergency response cost and debris and repairing. You have 10 counties that are under the President's disaster declaration. Those are Burnett, Kendall, Kerr, Kimball, Lano, Mason, McCullough, Menard, San Saba, and Tom Green. Both Travis and Williamson counties are, it appears to us they have met their threshold. We're working with them to get the documentation to FEMA. We expect those to be turned on very soon.  I want to let you know we have over 2300 state employees working under the governor's direction to support our local government partners. But a number that continues to blow me away is the over 13,000 volunteers just coming out to help anywhere they can. We're grateful for the volunteers, but I need help getting the message to the volunteers also.  In each of these communities, we will be establishing volunteer reception centers. The idea is for your volunteers to go to those sites so that we can match up your capabilities and skills with the needs of the community. We also want to be able to communicate with you. Up in Kerr County, on the Guadalupe River, we've had a tactical pause for a day and a half now  because of the rain in the waters that are coming down that river. We cannot afford to have people in the water and right next to the water that are not Swift Water Rescue trained and capable of at least saving themselves from being near that water because of the amount of rainfall that we're getting. Please help us communicate with the volunteers.  think a volunteer that's out there if you see them helping do everything you can to make sure they understand the message and we will continue to work together to support our partners. And finally governor to your point and 25 other states not counting ours focused on this it has been a tremendous response from the nation. Thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Thank you. One thing that Chief Kidd mentioned is worth re-emphasizing and that is those who lose their life by driving into water. Those who lost their lives at Camp Mystic has  Those stories have been told a lot, and it's tragic and horrendous. Less told are those who have lost their lives because they chose to drive into water and got swept away. The power of water sweeping a vehicle away is far more extreme than what most people know.  As waters rise over the coming days, could be in the Uvalde area, wherever it may be, people should drive with caution, knowing that you are totally in control of protecting your life and saving your life by not putting it into danger in the first place.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We'll take a few questions.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Sure. First, I will tell you this, because I did not share this with you earlier. I didn't mention those who were missing in the greater Kerrville area, which is 97 reported as of now. Let me first tell you an issue about those who are missing, then I'm going to answer your question.  So everybody who is at a camp, everybody who is at a hotel and places like that, they've been identified. Those who are missing on this list, most of them, were more difficult to identify because there was no record of them logging in anywhere. And it was through information provided by a friend, a family member, co-worker, whatever the case may be, that they haven't been found. Even though we are reporting 97 people missing,  There's no certainty that all 97 of those people were swept away by the storm. That point aside, to more specifically answer your question, and that is, the goal obviously is to continue to find those who are alive.  For those who have passed away, it's so important to closure for their families that we find them and identify them. Sometimes it does require using DNA testing to identify who they are and identify who their family is to make sure that we connect appropriately, correctly, the family member with the person who lost their lives. And sometimes that takes a few days to complete that process.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: But what I'm hearing now is telling me that they were added late, finally, to that declaration.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Sure. So it is truly a mathematical construct that Chief Kidd has mastered. I'm going to have him answer that question in general but also for Travis County.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So great question and thank you for that. Two parts to it. One is the governor's declaration. There was no delay in getting these counties on the governor's declaration once we knew that they were in the target area. That's part one.  Part two is the individual assistance for both of these counties, which is the money that goes and is made available to homeowners and renters, is already turned on in these counties as well. What we're working through right now is the public assistance, and that is a mathematical equation, as the governor said, based on the population of a county and the amount of damage that FEMA can certify in that county. The less populated counties have a much smaller threshold, $500,000, $600,000 versus millions of dollars for these two populated counties.  I am confident both counties have met their threshold, and I would bet by today or tomorrow we get answers back on these counties. I also want to say that does not delay any of the work that's going on. Waiting for those federal declarations to come in does not slow down rescue, does not slow down search, does not slow down additional law enforcement or additional fire protection or emergency medical services, nor has it been slowing down the debris removal, getting roads and driveways opened up.  So, don't mix the declaration with the response, please.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Thank you for the question.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So, I'll tell you this. The medical examiner's offices have been working pretty well and pretty timely.  There was a backlog and there were challenges because of local JPs in Kerr County that were slowing things down, holding things up, and it required pressure from the state and others to make sure that they began to expedite that process. When a life is lost, that family wants access to their loved one as quickly as possible. It was inexcusable for some local JPs to slow that process down.  But as far as medical examiners are concerned, I've heard no complaints about the speed with which they're working.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Governor, you're in Big Sandy Creek and meeting and talking to people there. A lot of them are frustrated. They, of course, wanted help to come the day before. What was the feel that you got in talking to those people? And did you feel that they heard you? And did you hear them?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So I met with, I don't know how many people, more than a dozen. And the first impression and the strongest impression I got was, one, a gratitude. They were happy that we were there, happy with everything we were doing. They were grateful for the temporary bridge that had been built. The other one, the other way to describe it is unity. They were unified. It was those people who lived there that came up and said, listen, we're community. We're Texas strong. We're hanging together. And they're neighbor helping neighbor.  And so I was impressed once again with the strength and commitment and moral clarity of our fellow Texans for uniting at a time as tough as this is.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: The response from other states has been amazing. We've got teams that are now picking up the load, letting the local guys get back to the basic service. And it's not necessarily basic, it's still important service. How important is having this heavy lifting going on from all these other states? So these guys here, Travis County, being one of them, getting back to basic service.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Everything all these other states is doing is extremely important. If I could say that one was more important than another, it would be what they are all doing in search and rescue operations. As Chief Kidd noted, our number one goal is protecting lives and finding lives. When I was at Big Sandy Creek, I met with search and rescue teams from Florida who were there in the water working  all day long to locate anybody they can find. That requires heavy volume. It requires manpower, walking every inch of a, it could be a creek, a river, whatever the case may be, to ensure that they are scouring every inch of earth in the state of Texas where a body could be found.  is benefit or aided by search dogs. And whenever we've had dog teams that have flown in from other states across the entire country. And so the response that we've been able to provide, especially as it concerns search and rescue operations, has been magnified many times over because of these teams who have stepped in from other states and given us the extra manpower as well as other resources to make sure we are better capable and quicker at taking on that task.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So yeah, I'm gonna give you the number so the number I read to you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It was given to me by Chief Nim kid and he was on the phone before we came in here and I'll let him explain this number.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thank you. So the number that we got from the Texas Department of Public Safety is 97 missing from the Guadalupe River flooding. That does not count the numbers that the governor read to you from the three counties that were here earlier. I think that'll put the total statewide at about 101 total, if I have that right.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: What do you mean by Guadalupe River? Most of those are in Kerr County. I think there has been some in Kendall County. Yes.  So one thing I think most state governors, most state officials, as well as the federal government could agree upon, and that is we needed improvements in FEMA. And it needed to be what I call right sized so that it would be more nimble, quicker in the response.  but also understanding that it's the locals who know what is best in responding to a disaster. And local is defined by these local communities, whether it be Leander or Travis County or Williamson County, whatever the case may be, they're the ones on the ground, and they know their communities far better than anybody else, and they know how to respond to their communities, and it's the state and federal government  that work to provide them the additional resources they need to accomplish their goal. Here's the point, but by working on the reforms that we will work with FEMA and with the presidential team on, we're going to work to find ways to streamline the process, cut through all the red tape, to ensure that even when we do that,  The monetary resources that we are receiving now, they're much needed for things like having the emergency first responders or debris removal or search and rescue operations. Those will still be funded, but we will have the ability to do it a whole lot faster, a whole lot quicker without waiting around for the federal government.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Governor, with all due respect, I know we're going to leave time, but I did want to ask a separate thing. Earlier today, the Secretary of State said that she's been talking to five or two of the United States to have state detention facilities in preparation for the State of the Union. I'd like to ask if you could attest to the conversation that's been going on in the State of the Union.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So, I haven't had a direct conversation with her. I do know that Texas has offered detention facilities. I've signed what's called a 287G law that was passed in the session that requires local jails to work with Homeland Security. Listen, we want to do everything we can to make sure that those who are here legally  are allowed to remain legally, those who are here illegally, they'll be turned over to ICE.

summary.SPEAKER_01: SPEAKER_01, likely a local official from Travis County, provides an update on their specific response efforts. They report on the number of rescues performed, the support received from the Governor's office and TDEM, and the challenges faced in the recovery process. They emphasise the long-term commitment to supporting the community.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Chief Nimcat from Texas Division of Emergency Management, provides details on the state's emergency response. He discusses the federal assistance declarations, the number of state employees and volunteers deployed, and the ongoing search and rescue operations. He emphasises the importance of public safety messages and the challenges in coordinating recovery efforts across different counties.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Governor Abbott emphasises the catastrophic flooding and storm damage across Texas, declaring a state of disaster in 21 counties. He reports on the ongoing search and rescue efforts, the number of fatalities and missing persons, and the widespread infrastructure damage. The Governor acknowledges the immense support from local responders, volunteers, and 25 other states. He stresses the importance of community unity and resilience, and notes the challenges in identifying missing individuals and expediting recovery processes.
summary.Unidentified SPEAKER: The Unidentified SPEAKER mentions that additional communities surrounding Uvalde, Del Rio, and Concan are now at risk and that resources are being deployed to prepare them for potential flooding.
summary.high_level_summary: Governor Abbott of Texas provides an update on the severe flooding and storms impacting numerous counties across the state. He announces a state of disaster for 21 counties, with additional communities now at risk. The focus remains on saving lives, with ongoing search and rescue operations, and recovery efforts. The Governor highlights the significant support from local first responders, volunteers, and 25 other states providing resources and assistance. The situation is dire, with numerous fatalities, missing persons, and widespread damage to infrastructure and homes.

video_title: Texas Emergency Management Chief Says There Are Currently '97 Missing' After Devastating Floods

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: task. So yeah, I'm gonna give you the number. So the number I read to you, it was given to me by Chief Nim kid and he was on the phone before we came in here and I'll let him explain this number.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you. So the number that we got from the Texas Department of Public Safety is 97 missing from the Guadalupe River flooding. That does not count the numbers that the governor read to you from the three counties that were here earlier. I think that'll put the total statewide at about 101 total if I have that right.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: What do you mean by Guadalupe River? Most of those are in Kerr County. I think there has been some in Kendall County. Yes.  Governor, you serve on President Trump's Human Review Council.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Shares the number of missing persons from the Texas Department of Public Safety and clarifies that it doesn't include counts from three other counties. Estimates the total statewide missing persons to be around 101.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Provides a number of missing persons given to them by Chief Nim Kid. Questions the attribution of the Guadalupe River flooding casualties to Kerr County.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses casualty numbers from flooding in Texas. There is confusion about the attribution of missing persons reports to specific locations.

video_title: Ron Johnson Confronted By Contituent For Big Beautiful Bill Stripping Her Husband Of Health Coverage

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Let's go to canteen and we're seeing will continue to thanks for staying on line with your question.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: There I thank you for having a town hall today. My question to you is that even though you get time for the for the bill and everything you ever consider about lower and middle income people how this will hurt my husband work. 9 to 5 every day at a hardware. At the metal fine that  Medicaid so he can go and get better so he can work. And by you putting in the money for it, my husband doesn't have coverage to work a full time job. And I'm looking at getting a second job just to be able to pay for Medicare. Did you ever consider about the people that you are hurting by signing this bill?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, the work requirement for Medicaid eligibility, by the way, Wisconsin did not expand Medicaid. So we have we have Medicaid based on  where you are in terms of the federal poverty line. So again, we didn't expand it. That may change because we're not fixing the Obamacare addition, which is, again, putting at risk Medicaid for the truly vulnerable. So again, Wisconsin is slightly different than most states who are completely abusing the process. And again, I think what's unfortunate is we just may see Wisconsin really engage in the same type of behavior that other states are, which is just  not feasible. So I've got a pretty good video up on my ex-post where we're talking about Republican leaders say we don't have a revenue problem, we have a spending problem. Again, $4.4 to $7 trillion, I hope most people recognize, that's completely unjustified. It's not like we're spending too little. We're spending way too much, and we're wasting too much money. I realize the media, I realize Democrat lies. We're talking about all these cuts. All we're doing is reducing the growth in spending, which is completely unsustainable.  So I know you're probably concerned and afraid because all that scare mongering, but we're not cutting spending on these programs. We're just trying to fix the problem of Medicaid, of Obamacare's addition to Medicaid, which puts all that at risk. As Elon Musk says in that video, if we don't fix this, there won't be money for any of these things. And one of the reasons people got pretty snarly during the 2024 election is because the 40-year high inflation caused by  massive, out-of-control deficit spending that we can't afford. And he devalued the dollar. I laid out those different pre-pandemic levels of spending from 98, 2014, 2019. I also took a look at, what is your dollar worth? Your 1998 dollar is now worth $0.51. A dollar you held in 2014 is worth $0.74. A dollar you held as recently as 2019 is worth $0.80. That is wiping out people's savings.  making all these goods and services, you know, unaffordable. And again, that's all because of massive government deficit spending. But again, I don't think the solution was a massive $4 trillion tax increase on every single America, which is what we're looking at, had we not passed the recent bill. But Katina, thanks for staying in line. Appreciate your question.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Expresses concern about the new bill affecting her husband's Medicaid coverage. She worries that the work requirement will force her to get a second job to pay for Medicare. She fears the bill will hurt people like her husband who work hard but rely on Medicaid.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Defends the bill, explaining that Wisconsin has not expanded Medicaid and that the work requirement is necessary to address the abuse of the system by other states. He emphasises the need to control government spending, arguing that current levels are unsustainable and are causing inflation. The speaker claims that the bill is not cutting spending but reducing the growth in spending and that failing to address the issue will lead to the collapse of Medicaid and other programs.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a new bill that impacts Medicaid eligibility. The concern is that the bill, which aims to control spending, may hurt lower-middle-income families by reducing Medicaid coverage and introducing work requirements. The speaker defends the bill, emphasising the need to address unsustainable government spending and inflation caused by excessive deficit spending.

video_title: Hakeem Jeffries Shreds Texas GOP For Voting To Hold Special Gerrymandering Session Following Floods

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Democrats in the Senate have been working incredibly hard to push back aggressively against Donald Trump's extreme agenda. We partnered closely with Senate Democrats under the leadership of Chuck Schumer to strongly and uniformly oppose Donald Trump's one big ugly bill. And I'm confident that Senate Republicans will continue  to rubber stamp Donald Trump's extreme judicial choices, and Senate Democrats will continue to aggressively push back on behalf of the American people. This whole situation that America has found itself in over the last six-plus months has been one big corrupt, chaotic, and cruel project  that has been unleashed on the American people and it continues. I mean this Texas thing shouldn't surprise anyone because despite the claims by house Republican leaders that the American people have fallen in love with these extremists in the house of representatives and so they're acting upon a mandate. Give me a break. The only reason  The only reason that house Republicans even have a majority right now is because they stole three seats from the people of North Carolina. North Carolina is a 50 50 state. Donald Trump narrowly won the state in 2024. It's a democratic governor, a democratic lieutenant governor, a democratic attorney general, democratic elected officials across the state.  of North Carolina who won on the same day. North Carolina is a 50-50 state. The North Carolina Congressional Delegation, which previously had fair congressional lines, produced a 50-50 congressional delegation. Seven Democrats, seven Republicans, as recently as January 2nd of this year. That was the makeup of the North Carolina Congressional Delegation. What happened?  Republicans engaged in mid-decade redistricting in a 50-50 state that had fair maps and produced an evenly divided delegation, and took it from 7-7, stole three seats that were in Democratic hands from the people of North Carolina as a result of illegitimate mid-decade congressional gerrymandering, and turned that delegation into 10 Republicans and four Democrats.  There's a three seat difference in the House of Representatives right now when Republicans are at full strength and Democrats are at full strength. 220 Republicans to 215 Democrats. That entire difference, the majority that Republicans have can be explained solely by the fact that they cheated in North Carolina. These people have zero credibility.  in terms of the issues that they're allegedly championing on behalf of the American people. If you believed in your ideas and the power of your issues, then why are you trying to cheat now in Texas, just like you did in North Carolina? The problem that Republicans confront is that the Texas congressional map is already gerrymandered.  And so this gerrymander may actually turn into a dummy-mander because they are going to create a situation where four, five, six, seven, eight Republicans who are currently in safe districts are going to be on the front line of our efforts to flip seats, particularly in a midterm election where Donald Trump is deeply unpopular and his signature one big ugly bill.  is deeply unpopular. Imagine a group of people, this is how corrupt they are, who in the middle of a search and rescue operation that is taking place in Texas right now, dozens of children drowned to death. Some of that has to do with incompetence in the Texas state government and incompetence in the Trump administration.  And instead of actually trying to be there for the people of Texas and the hill country, children at summer camp, who's lost their lives, they call a special session. And the main reason for that special session is to try to steal the midterm elections by rigging the Texas congressional map. These people are complete and total embarrassment.  The American people are not going to stand for it. And things aren't going to get better for them. Politically, they're only going to get worse. Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker denounces Republican tactics, particularly gerrymandering in North Carolina and Texas, portraying them as corrupt and undemocratic. They argue that these actions have resulted in an unfair Republican majority in the House of Representatives and criticise the timing of the Texas special session, suggesting it is insensitive to the state's crises.
summary.high_level_summary: The speaker criticises Republican actions in North Carolina and Texas, accusing them of gerrymandering and political corruption to gain an unfair advantage. They argue that Republicans cheated in North Carolina to secure a majority in the House of Representatives and are now attempting to do the same in Texas. The speaker also highlights the timing of the Texas special session, calling it insensitive and prioritising political gain over addressing the state's crises.

video_title: Chuck Schumer Torches Republicans Over 'Horrible Cuts' In 'Big, Ugly Bill' And Rescissions Package

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: This week, Senate Republicans are set to push through the Senate a bill that betrays rural communities, harms global health, weakens America's standing abroad, and, worst of all, sets the stage for even more harmful cuts down the line. The so-called rescissions package continues the destructive Republican pattern. Cut now, ask questions later. The same thing that's happening with FEMA and the National Weather Service is happening right here.  Again, use that chainsaw. Cut, cut, cut. Don't look at what you're cutting, what its effect will be, whether it's waste or whether it's sinew and bone. And then later say, oh, maybe we shouldn't have done that. And you know what, Mr. President? Our Republican senators, most of them know this is wrong, but they're so afraid of Donald Trump  Yesterday, he threatened any of them who voted against the full rescissions package that we have before us would face his wrath. What is going on here? Does anyone stand up to these horrible, horrible cuts that hurt the American people? Republicans in real time are cutting health care. They're cutting education. They're cutting aid for our veterans. Veterans are not getting, they asked them,  The veterans know they're not getting the health care they used to. And making things even worse, Donald Trump's tariffs are coming in at the worst possible time. And in a few short months, they're going to raise the cost of groceries. They're going to hurt small businesses and do untold damage to our economy. And now this package suffocates public broadcast. Well, did they even know when they said they wanted to cut it? You know, Donald Trump doesn't seem to like it.  How much it helps our rural communities? It's the only place they can rely on for local news, for weather reports? That farmers across rural America depend on public broadcast to get weather reports? Because there's no other way? Do they know that it guts international aid that ensures America's national security?  Did they even think of the consequences? Just because Donald Trump says he wants it cut, and everyone knows he doesn't know the details of any of this stuff. The rescissions package is certainly troubling, but the pattern behind it is even worse. It sets the stage for even more party-line devastating cuts in the future, to health care, to education, anything Republicans decide they don't like, all on a party-line vote, all because of obeisance and fear of Donald Trump.  not a conviction that he's doing the right thing. This is a dark omen moving forward. Our Republican friends say they fight for the middle class. They say they fight for working people. Then they turn around and take investments away from the middle class in rural America. I urge them, urge them, not to proceed with this bill as written. Now on health care costs. Republicans' big ugly betrayal will devastate American health care this year.  Not many years down the line. Not a few years down the line. It's going to hurt now. There's a growing idea among Republican members of Congress and then the lobbyists who talk to the press all the time that hospitals don't need to worry about the big ugly bill because there's time to stave off or change the horrible Medicaid cuts Republicans passed and are now running away from. That's garbage.  Donald Trump and Republican leaders forced their members to walk the plank and cut Medicaid to the bone. So now they're in damage control mode. They know how bad it is. They want to make their big, ugly bill seem less destructive and seem more palpable, when in reality, it's quite literally a death sentence for rural hospitals and vulnerable Americans. And that death sentence for so many of them is not two years away. It's now. Here are the facts.  that show Republicans' big, ugly betrayal is having an impact right now, not later. At least 300 rural hospitals are at immediate risk of closing because of this bill. Already, already, not two years from now, now, this week, two weeks after the bill passed, hospitals in Iowa, Nebraska, North Carolina, and Maine have announced their closing or are in serious danger of closing, not in 2027,  Not in 2028. Now. Now. Governors in at least eight states, eight states, have called special sessions this summer. Not in 2028. Not in 2027. They've called special sessions this summer. Or are pushing stopgap subsidies to shield doctors and hospitals from the immediate harm. States don't see the big ugly bill as a problem for years from now. To them, to the workers,  And most of all, to the people who get health care in a lot of these rural hospitals, it's a problem right now. And this fall, more problems. Not in 2028, folks. This fall, people will get notices that their insurance premiums for the Affordable Care Act will go up 75 percent on average because Republicans chose not to extend tax credits for the ACA.  This will also impact people on private insurance. If you don't have ACA, Medicaid, Medicare, you're still going to get increases in your insurance. Everyone is affected by these cuts. Just about everyone. Unless you're one of those billionaires who self-insures. You don't have to have insurance because you've got all the money in the world to pay any medical bill. That's not true of the vast majority of Americans. And what they're doing is just the start. Republicans have made it clear they want even deeper cuts to Medicaid.  Many in the House Freedom Caucus, those right-wingers, have said they weren't satisfied with their big, ugly bill. So, who is to say that Donald Trump and Russell Vogt won't use rescissions or another reconciliation bill to cut for health care even deeper? And what are our Republican colleagues going to do when the handful of right-wing Freedom Caucus people in this body and the other body  Say they demand cuts or they won't vote for any bill? Are they going to cave once again? Say, OK. Let me say it again. All this talk from Republicans that many of their own cuts won't materialize is utter nonsense. Hospitals are closing now. States are reacting now. Insurance companies are adjusting now. And the harm to the American people will happen now, not later.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker strongly opposes the Senate Republican rescissions package, calling it a betrayal of rural communities and a harmful pattern of indiscriminate cutting. They argue that the cuts are driven by fear of Trump rather than policy considerations, and will devastate healthcare, education, veterans aid, and public broadcast. The speaker emphasises the immediate consequences of these cuts, such as hospital closures and increased insurance premiums, and warns of even more severe damage in the future if the pattern continues.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation criticises a Senate Republican bill proposing significant cuts to various public services, which the speaker argues are reckless, harmful to the American people, and driven by fear of former President Donald Trump rather than sound policy decisions. The speaker emphasises the immediate and severe impacts of these cuts on rural communities, healthcare, education, and veterans, highlighting the contradictions in Republican claims and the potential for even deeper cuts in the future.

video_title: Trump Recounts Butler Shooting: 'My Life Was Saved By God To, Really, Make America Great Again'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And it's remarkable to think that it was only one year ago this week that my time on Earth nearly ended. And if you look at that, God was with me, because that's something that, in theory, I should not be with you today.  Well, I believe that, and I do believe it, that my life was saved by God to really make America great again. I really believe that. I think I have a son. He's a great shooter, like a championship shooter. Don and Eric was a great shooter, both of them. But they said that at that distance with that gun,  You didn't have a chance. And we turned the head at the right time, didn't we, huh? We turned the head at the right time. So, I don't know, some people say it was lucky and some people say something else. I say something else. I think God helped us.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker recounts a near-death experience from a year ago, emphasising that they should not be alive today. They believe God saved them for a specific purpose, which is to "make America great again". The speaker also mentions their sons, Don and Eric, and implies that they are skilled shooters.
summary.high_level_summary: The speaker recounts a life-threatening incident from a year ago, attributing their survival to divine intervention, and suggests this has a greater purpose.

video_title: JUST IN: Chuck Grassley Details New Findings From Major Report On Trump Assassination Attempt

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: The Senator from Iowa. On July the 13th, 2024, an assassin nearly killed President Trump. The gunman injured him and two rally participants and killed Corey Comitera. We keep him, his family in our prayers as well as everyone affected that day.  Today, one year and one day later, I come to the floor to provide an update on my ongoing oversight of that attempted assassination. The day of the shooting, I launched an investigation focused on gathering and releasing information to the public. I didn't want the public to be kept in the dark.  Public transparency stops conspiracy theories. 60 years after JFK's assassination, we still have questions being asked. Unfortunately, there are still aspects to that shooting where the government hasn't been transparent. The Biden administration stonewalled my oversight requests.  I strongly urge the new administration to let all the facts breathe, unlike the last administration. The day of the shooting, my oversight unit quickly got to work. They talked to patriotic whistleblowers. They informed dozens of witnesses and interviewed them, including local law enforcement officials.  rally goers, and local businesses. I have staff obtained and reviewed weeks worth of security footage, text messages, pictures, law enforcement briefing materials, after action reports, and still other records. They also obtained police body camera  camera footage that provided the first video of what happened in the aftermath of that shooting. I made it all public. At the time, my investigative work unveiled the most detailed picture of the Trump assassination attempt. As part of my oversight, I asked the Department of Homeland Security Inspector General  to review the matter. I also requested the Government Accountability Office to do the same as I asked the Inspector General to do. The American people wanted answers. They wanted accountability in the aftermath of this tragedy. I have worked hard to do just that. And I know there's more work to be done.  This past weekend, the Government Accountability Office produced me its report on the July 13 assassination attempt. The Government Accountability Office report starts by stating, quote, the U.S. Secret Service failed to implement security measures  that could have prevented the assassination attempt on then former President Donald J. Trump during a July 13th, 2024 campaign rally," end quote. According to the report, prior to the July 13th rally,  Secret Service received information from the intelligence community about a threat against President Trump's life. Yet, this threat information wasn't shared with Secret Service personnel or local law enforcement officials, all responsible for securing that event.  Clearly, had all federal, state, and local law enforcement officials known of this threat, it would have changed how they secured the AGR building where the sniper opened fire from. As I previously made public, Secret Service and its local partners had cell phone issues on July 13th. The Government Accountability Office report  found that Secret Service didn't have a policy to assess cellular service at the site, even though communication is key during any major event like this. This resulted in the Secret Service not receiving real-time threat information and updates during the search for the gunman. Every delayed second  in finding the gunman meant that he was one step closer to carrying out his evil objective. I previously made public documents showing that the Secret Service had issues with counter drone system at the rally. The General Government Accountability Office confirmed my previous oversight.  GAO found that the Secret Service's counter drone operator lacked the training, the knowledge, and support to fix and operate the counter drone system. According to the Government Accountability Office report, these problems occurred because the Secret Service didn't follow its own requirements that personnel  must complete training before operating a counter drone system. The GEO report says the Secret Service said using a counter drone is like turning on a flashlight. Yet the counter drone did not work and the Secret Service could not fix it. Had a counter drone been operating as planned,  It could have identified the shooter's drone and even the shooter. The Government Accountability Office's report also found that Secret Service planned to use farm equipment to address a line-of-sight issue when securing the AGR building. Before the rally,  A campaign staffer asked Secret Service to modify the plan, which the advance team did as the staffer requested. But they didn't notify senior officials overseeing the rally of these changes. If they had, the senior officials might have overruled them. While the report says the Secret Service has made changes direct  correct some of these problems, they still have more work to do. The Secret Service operates in a zero-fail mission, and they don't have room for any error. Every failure exposed by the Government Accountability Office report must be turned into positive changes in the Secret Service.  I want my colleagues to know that I'll be riding herd on them until I'm satisfied the job is done. I want to close out by thanking the law enforcement officers serving on the front lines, including the Secret Service, Capitol Police, their law enforcement partners, and of course their families, all working hard and sacrificing to keep the public and the government safe. I am grateful  to you all and do not in the future then take the days that seem uneventful for granted. I yield the floor.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The Senator recounts the tragic events of the assassination attempt on former President Trump and emphasises the importance of public transparency in such investigations. They detail their oversight efforts, including interviewing witnesses, reviewing security footage, and obtaining various records. The Senator highlights the GAO report's findings, which criticise the Secret Service for failing to implement security measures, share threat information, and address communication and counter-drone system issues. The Senator urges the new administration to be more transparent and notes that while the Secret Service has made some changes, further improvements are necessary.
summary.high_level_summary: A Senator provides an update on their oversight of the attempted assassination of former President Trump on July 13, 2024. The Senator highlights the Secret Service's failures in implementing security measures, which led to the incident. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) report confirms these failures, including inadequate threat sharing, communication issues, and problems with the counter-drone system. The Senator emphasises the need for transparency and accountability, and notes that while the Secret Service has made some changes, more work is required.

video_title: Marsha Blackburn Makes The Case For Key Judicial Nominee

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you, Madam President. I ask that we dispense with the quorum call. Without objection. Thank you. Madam President, this is such a significant day. In just a few minutes, this chamber will vote to confirm Ms. Whitney Hermendorfer to serve on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. She is the very first judicial nomination of President Trump's second term.  And there is a good reason that the president selected Ms. Hermann-Dorfer for the circuit court. There is no one more qualified  to take on this important role as an appellate judge for our great nation. Now, a little bit about her background. She is a Tennessee native. She attended Nashville's Harpeth Hall School, and she was an outstanding athlete and an outstanding  student at the Harpeth Hall School, which as an educational institution has a really long history of producing and graduating remarkable women. And Ms. Hermann-Dorfer is one of those. She graduated magna cum laude from Princeton, and she was first in her law school class at GWU.  And it will not surprise my colleagues to learn that Ms. Hermendorfer's career has been a stellar career. After graduating from law school, she was an associate at Williams & Conley, where her practice focused on appellate litigation and regulatory and administrative law.  She also clerked for four federal judges, including three Supreme Court justices, Justice Alito, Justice Barrett, and then Judge Kavanaugh when he was on the D.C. Circuit. Since 2003, she has served as director of the Strategic Litigation Unit in the office of Tennessee Attorney General Jonathan Schermette.  In that role, she has not only been an aggressive attorney, she has led a team of talented attorneys  in the AG's office, fighting to protect the constitutional rights of Tennesseans. There is no doubt that she will serve our nation admirably on the Sixth Circuit. She will be a tireless advocate for our Constitution. She will show respect for the rule of law.  She will show respect for the Constitution as it is written. She will not be a judge who will try to rewrite it. She is eminently qualified to serve, and I urge all my colleagues to vote to confirm her nomination. I yield the floor and note the absence of a quorum. The clerk will call the roll. Ms. Alsobrooks.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker introduces the nomination of Ms. Whitney Hermendorfer to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. They praise Hermendorfer's qualifications, emphasising her academic excellence, stellar career, and her experience clerking for four federal judges, including three Supreme Court Justices. The speaker urges colleagues to vote in favour of her confirmation, asserting she will be a tireless advocate for the Constitution and respect the rule of law.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation is a speech in the Senate advocating for the confirmation of Ms. Whitney Hermendorfer to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The speaker highlights Hermendorfer's qualifications, education, and career achievements.

video_title: 'Decimates Food Assistance For 42 Million Americans': Deborah Ross Blasts GOP's 'Big Ugly Law'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Without objection, the gentlewoman is recognized for one minute. Mr. Speaker, I rise today to condemn Republicans' big, ugly law, which decimates food assistance for 42 million Americans, including millions of children, seniors, veterans, and people with disabilities.  Erica from Wilson, North Carolina had this to say about SNAP. As a grandmother who's having to raise my granddaughter, this program helps me. I survived three heart attacks, yet I'm still able to make sure my granddaughter is taken care of.  At a time when so many families are struggling to put food on the table, why would we take away a lifeline that millions of Americans rely on? This past weekend, I visited Christ the King Lutheran Church in Cary, North Carolina, where I saw firsthand indispensable work to combat food insecurity in our own community.  Republicans have abandoned vulnerable, hungry people to pay for tax cuts for billionaires. It's shameful and un-American. Thank you and I yield back.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker opposes a Republican law reducing food assistance, arguing it harms millions including children, seniors, veterans and disabled people. She shares personal stories and community observations to illustrate her point and condemns the law as shameful and un-American.
summary.high_level_summary: The speaker criticises a Republican law that cuts food assistance, highlighting its impact on vulnerable Americans and contrasting it with tax cuts for billionaires.
